div.p: With the humours of Sir Iohn Falstaffe▪ As also the swaggering vaine of Ancient Pistoll, and Corporall Nym.
LONDON: Printed by T. H. for R. Meighen, and are to be sold at his Shop, next to the Middle-Temple Gate, and in S. Dunstans Church-yard in Fleet-street, 1630.

div.head: Scena prima.
div.stage: Enter Iustice Shallow, Slender, Sir Hugh Euans, Master Page, Falstoffe, Bardolph, Nym, Pistoll, Anne Page, Mistresse Ford, Mistresse Page, Simple.

sp.speaker: Shallow.
sp.p: SIr Hugh, perswade mee not: I will make a Star-Chamber matter of it, if he were twenty Sir Iohn Falstoffe, hee shall not abuse Robert Shadow Esquire.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: In the County of Glocester, Iustice of Peace and Coram.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I (Cosen Slender) and Cust▪ alorum.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I, and Rotulorum too; and a Gentleman borne (Master Parson) who writes himselfe Armigero, in any Bill, Warrant, Quittance, or Obligation, Armigero.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I that I doe, and haue done any time these three hundred yeeres.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: All his successors (gone before him) hath don't: and all his Ancestors (that come after him) may: they may giue the dozen white Luces in their Coate.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: It is an olde Coate.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: The dozen white Lowses doe become an olde Coat well: it agrees well passant: It is a familiar beast to man, and signifies Loue.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: The Luse is the fresh-fish, the salt-fish is an old Coate.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I may quarter (Coz).

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: You may, by marrying.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: It is marring indeed, if he quarter it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Not a whit.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Yes per-lady: if hee ha's a quarter of your coate, there is but three Shirts for your selfe, in my simple coniectures; but that is all one: if Sir Iohn Falstaffe haue committed disparagements vnto you▪ I am of the Church and will be glad to doe my beneuolence, to make attonements and compremises betweene you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: The Councell shall heare it, it is a Riot.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: It is not meet the Councell heare a Riot: there is no feare of Got in a Riot: The Councell (looke you) shall desire to heare the feare of Got, and not to heare a Riot: take your viza-ments in that.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Ha; o'my life, if I were yong againe, the sword should end it.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: It is petter that friends is the sword, and end it: and there is also another deuice in my praine, which peraduenture prings goot discretions with it. There is Anne Page, which is daughter to Master Thomas Page, which is pretty virginity.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Mistris Anne. Page? shee has browne haire, and speakes small like a woman.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: It is that ferry person for all the world, as iust as you will desire, and seuen hundred pounds of Moneies, and Gold, & Siluer, is her Grand▪ sire vpon his deaths-bed (Got deliuer to a ioyfull resurrections) giue, when she is able to ouertake seuenteene yeeres old. It were a goot motion, if we leaue our pribbles and prabbles, and desire a marriage betweene Master▪ Abraham, and Mistris Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Did her Grand, sire leaue her seauen hundred pound▪

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I, and her father is make her a petter penny.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I know the young Gentlewoman, she has good gifts.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Seuen hundred pounds, & possibilities, is goot gifts.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Wel, let vs see honest Master Page is Falstaffe there▪

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Shall I tell you a lye? I doe despise a lyer, as I doe despise one that is false, or as I despise one that is not true: the Knight Sir Iohn is there, and I beseech you be ruled by your well-willers: I will peat the doore for Master Page. What hoa? Got-plesse your house heere.

sp.speaker: Master Page.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Euen.
sp.p: Here is go 't's plesting and your friend, and Iustice Shallow, & heere young Master Slender: that peraduentures shall tell you another tale, if matters grow to your likings.

sp.speaker: Master Page.
sp.p: I am glad to see your Worships well: I thanke you for my Venison Master Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Master Page, I am glad to see you: much good doe it your good heart: I wish'd your Venison better, it was ill killed: how doth good Mistresse Page? and I thanke you alwaies with my heart, la▪ with my heart.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Sir, I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir, I thanke you: by yea, and no I doe.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: I am glad to see you, good Master Slender.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: How do's your fallow Greyhound, Sir, I heard say he was out▪ run on Cotsall.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: It could not be iudg'd, Sir,

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: You'll not confesse: you'll not confesse.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: That hee will not, 'tis your fault: 'tis your fault: 'tis a good dogge.

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: A Cur, Sir.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir: hee's a good dog, and a faire dog, can there be more said? he is good and faire. Is Sir Iohn Falstaffe heerr?

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: Sir, hee is within: and I would I could doe a good office betweene you.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: It is spoke as a Christians ought to speake.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: He hath wrong'd me Master Page.)

sp.speaker: M. Pa.
sp.p: Sir, he doth in some sort confesse it.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: If it be confessed, it is not redressed; is not that so (M. Page?) he hath wrong'd me, indeed he hath, at a word he hath: belecue me, Robert Shallow Esquire, saith hee is wronged.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: Here comes Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Now, Master Shallow, you'll complaine of me to the King?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Knight, you haue beaten my men, kill'd my deere, and broke open my Lodge.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But not kiss'd your Keepers daughter?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Tut, a pin: this shall be answer'd.

lg.l: I will answer it strait, I haue done all this:
That is now answer'd.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: The Councell shall know this.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: 'T were better for you if it were known in Councell: you'll be laugh'd at.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Pauca verba; (Sir Iohn) good worts.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good worts? good Cabidge; Slender, I broke your head: what matter haue you against me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Marry sir, I haue matter in my head against you, and against your cony-catching Rascals, Bardolf, Nym, and Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You Banbery Cheese.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: How now, Mephostophilus?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I, it is no matter.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Slice, I say; pauca, pauca: Slice, that's my humor:

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Where's Simple my man? can you tell, Cosen?

sp.speaker: Eua.
sp.p: Peace, I pray you▪ now let vs vnderstand: there is three Vmpires in this matter, as I vnderstand; that is, Master Page (fidelicet Master Page,) and there is my selfe, (fidelicet my selfe) and the three party is (lastly, and finally) mine Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: We three to heare it, and end it between them:

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Ferry goo't, I will make a priefe of it in my note-booke, and we will afterwards orke vpon the cause, with as great discreetly as we can.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: He heares with eares.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: The Teuill and his Tam: what phrase is this? hee heares with eare? why, it is affectations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pistoll, did you picke M. Slenders purse?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I, by these gloues did he, or I would I might neuer come in mine owne great chamber againe else, of seauen groates in mill-sixpences, and two Edward Shouelboords, that cost me two shilling and two pence a peece of yead Miller: by these gloues.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Is this true, Pistoll?

sp.speaker: Fuan.
sp.p: No, it is false, if it is a picke-purse.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Ha, thou mountaine Forreyner: Sir Iohn, and Master mine, I combat challenge of this Latine Bilboe: word of deniall in thy labras here; word of deniall; froth, and scum thou liest.

sp.speaker: Slen▪
sp.p: By these gloues, then 'twas he.

sp.speaker: Nym.
sp.p: Be auis'd sir, and passe good humours: I will say marry trap with you, if you runne the nut-hooks humor on me, that is the very note of it.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: By this hat, then hee in the red face had it: for though I cannot remember what I did when you made me drunke, yet I am not altogether an asse.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What say you Scarlet, and Iohn?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Why sit, (for my part) I say the Gentleman had drunke himselfe out of his fiue sentences.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: It is his fiue sences: fie, what the ignorance is.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: And being fap, sir, was (as they say) casheerd: and so conclusions past the Car-eires.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I, you spake in Latten then to: but 'tis no matter; Ile nere be drunke whilst I liue againe, but in honest, ciuill, godly company for this tricke: if I be drunke, Ile bee drunke with those that haue the feare of God, and not with drunken knaues.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: So got udge me, that is a vertuous minde.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You heare all these matters deni'd, Gentlemen; you heare it.

sp.speaker: Ma. Page.
sp.p: Nay daughter, carry the wine in, wee'll drinke within.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Oh heauen: This is Mistresse Anne Page:

sp.speaker: Master Page.
sp.p: How now Mistris Ford?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mistris Ford, by my troth you are very well met: by your leaue good Mistris.

sp.speaker: Master Page.
sp.p: Wife bid these gentlemen welcome: come, we haue a hot Venison pasty to dinner; Come gentlemen, I hope we shall drinke downe all vnkindnesse.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I had rather then forty shillings I had my booke of Songs and Sonnets heere: How now Simple, where haue you beene? I must wait on my selfe, must I? you haue not the booke of Riddles about you, haue you?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Booke of Riddles? why did you not lend it to Alice Short-cake vpon Alhallowmas last, a fortnight afore Michaelmas.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Come Coz, come Coz, wee stay for you: a word with you Coz: marry this there is as 'twere a tender, a kinde of tender, made a faire-off by Sir Hugh here: doe you vnderstand me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I Sir, you shall finde me reasonable, if it be so, I shall doe that that it reason.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Nay, but vnderstand me▪

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: So I doe Sir.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Giue care to his motions; (Master Slender) I will description the matter to you, if you be capacity of it.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Nay, I will doe as my Cozen Shallow saies: I pray you pardon me, he's a Iustice of Peace in his Countrie, simple though I stand here.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: But that is not the question: the question is concerning your marriage.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I, there's the point Sir.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: Marry is it▪ the very point of it, to Mist. Anne▪ Page.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Why if it be so▪ I will marry hervpon any reasonable demands.

sp.speaker: Eu.
sp.p: But can you affection the'o man, let vs command to know that of your mouth, or of your lips: for diners Philosophers hold, that the lips is parcell of the mouth▪ therefore precisely, can you carry your good will to the maide?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Cosen Abraham Slender, can you loue her?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I hope sir, I will doe as it shall become one that would doe reason.

sp.speaker: Euan:
sp.p:
Nay, got's Lords, and his Ladies, you must speake
possitable, if you can carry-her your desires towards her.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: That you must.
Will you, (vpon good dowry) marry her?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I will doe a greater thing then that, vpon your request (Cosen) in any reason.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Nay conceiue mee, conceiue mee, (sweet Coz): what I doe is to pleasure you (Coz) can you loue the maid?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I will marry her (Sir) at your request; but if there be no great loue in the beginning, yet Heauen may decrease it vpon better acquaintance, when wee are married, and haue more occasion to know one another; I hope vpon familiarity will grow more content; but if you say mary-her, I will mary-her, that I am freely dissolued, and dissolutely.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: It is a fery discretion-answere; saue the fall is in the'ord, dissolutely; the ort is (according to our meaning) resolutely: his meaning is good.

sp.speaker: Sh▪
sp.p: I, I thinke my Cosen meant well.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I or else I would I might be hang'd (la▪)

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: Here comes faire Mistris Anne; would I were yong for your sake, Mistris Anne.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The dinner is on the Table, my Father desires your worships company.

sp.speaker: Sh.
sp.p: I will wait on him, (faire Mistris Anee.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Od's plessed-will; I will not be absence at the grace

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Wil't please your worship to come in, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: No, I thanke you forsooth, hartely; I am very well.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: The dinner attends you Sir.

sp.speaker: Sl.
sp.p: I am not a hungry, I thanke you, forsooth; goe Sirha, for all you are my man, goe waite vpon my Cosen Shallow; a Iustice of peace sometime may be beholding to his friend, for a Man; I keepe but three Men and a Boy yet, till my Mother be dead; but what though, yet I liue like a a poore Gentleman borne.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I may not goe in without your worship; they will not sit till you come.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I▪ faith, Ile eate nothing, I thanke you as much as though I did.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: I pray you Sir walke in.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I had rather walke here (I thanke you) I bruiz'd my shin th'other day, with playing at Sword and Dagger with a Master of Fence (three veneys for a dish of slew'd Prunes) and by my troth, I cannot abide the smell of hot meat since. Why doe your dogs barke so? be there Beares ith' Towne?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I thinke there are, Sir, I heard them talk'd of.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I loue the sport well, but I shall as soone quarrell at it, as any man in England, you are afraid if you see the Beare loose, are you not?

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I indeede Sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: That's meate and drinke to me now; I haue seene Sackerson loose, twenty times, and haue taken him by the Chaine, but (I warrant you) the women haue so cride and shrekt at it, that it past. But women indeede, cannot abide'em, they are very ill-fauour'd rough things.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: Come, gentle M. Slender, come; we stay for you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ile eate nothing, I thanke you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: By cocke and pie, you shall not choose, Sir: come, come.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Nay, pray you lead the way.

sp.speaker: Ma. Pa.
sp.p: Come on Sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Mistris Anne: your selfe shall goe first.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: Not I Sir, pray you keepe on.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Truely I will not goe first, truely-la▪ I will not doe you that wrong.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.p: I pray you Sir.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ile rather be vnmannerly, then troublesome, you do your selfe wrong indeede-la.

div.head: Scena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Euans, and Simple.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Go your wayes, and aske of Doctor Caius house,
which is the way; and there dwels one Mistris Quickly; which is in the manner of his Nurse; or his dry-Nurse; or his Cooke; or his Laundry; his Washer, and his Ringer.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Nay, it is petter yet; giue her this letter; for▪ t is a'oman that altogeathers acquaintance with Mistris Anne Page; and the Letter is to desire, and require her to solicite your Masters desires, to Mistris Anne Page. I pray you bee gon: I will make an end of my dinner; ther's Pippins and Cheese to come.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Falstaeffe, Host, Bardolfe, Nym, Pistoll, Page.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mine Host of the Garter?

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: What saies my Bully Rooke? speake schollerly, and wisely.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Truely mine Host; I must turne away some of my followers.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Discard, (bully Hercules) casheere; let them wag; trot, trot.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I sit at ten pounds a weeke.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Thou'rt an Emperor (Cesar, Keiser and Pheazar) I will entertaine Bardolfe; he shall draw; he shall tap; said I well (bully Hector?)

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Doe so (good mine Host.)

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: I haue spoke, let him follow, let me see thee froth, and liue: I am at a word: follow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolfe, follow him; a Tapster is a good trade, an old Cloake, makes a new Ierkin, a wither'd Seruingman, a fresh Tapster; goe, adew.

sp.speaker: Ba.
sp.p: It is a life that I haue desir'd, I will thriue.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: O base hungarian wight, wilt thou the spigot wield:

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: He was gotten in drinke, is not the humor conceited

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I am glad I am so acquit of this Tinderbox, his Thefts were too open, his filching was like an vnskilfull Singer, he kept not time.

sp.speaker: Nim.
sp.p: The good humor is to steale at a minuntes rest.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Conuay: the wise it call: Steale? foh: a fico for the phrase.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well sirs, I am almost out at heeles.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Why then let Kibes ensue.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: There is no remedy: I must conicatch, I must shift,

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Yong Rauens must haue foode.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Which of you know Ford of this Towne?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: I ken the wight; he is of substance good.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: My honest Lads, I will tell you what I am about.

sp.speaker: Pist,
sp.p: Two yards, and more.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No quips now Pistoll; (Indeede I am in the wast two yards about; but I am now about no waste: I am about thrift) briefely; I doe meane to make loue to Fords wife; I spie entertainment in her, shee discourses, shee craues, she giues the leere of inuitation; I can construe the action of her familier stile, and the hardest voice of her behauior (to be english'd rightly) is I am Sir Iohn Falstafs.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: He hath studied her will; and translated her will out of honesty, into English.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The Anchor is deepe; will that humor passe?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Now, the report goes, she has all the rule of her husbands Purse; he hath a legend of Angels.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: As many diuels entertaine; and to her Boy say I.

sp.speaker: Ni
sp.p: The humor rises it is good; humor me the angels.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I haue writ me here a letter to her; and here another to Pages wife, who euen now gaue me good eyes too; examind my parts with most iudicious illiads; sometimes the beame of her view, guilded my foote, sometimes my portly belly.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Then did the Sun on dung-hill shine.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I thanke thee for that humour.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
O she did so course o're my exteriors with such a greedy intention, that the appetite of her eye, did seeme to scorch mee vp like a burning-glasse; here's another letter to her; She beares the Purie too; Shee is a Region in Guiana; all gold, and bountie; I will be Cheaters to them both, and they shall be Exchequers to mee; they
shall be my East and West Indies, and I will trade to them both; Goe, beare thou this Letter to Mistris Page; and thou this to Mistris Ford; wee will thriue (Lads) wee will thriue.

lg.l: Shall I Sir Pandarus of Troy become,
And by my side weare Steele? then Lucifer take all.
I will run no base humor; here take the humor-Letter;
I will keepe the hauior of reputation.
Hold Sirha, beare you these Letters rightly,
Saile like my Pinnasse to these golden shores.
Rogues, hence, auaunt, vanish like haile-stones; goe,
Trudge; plod away ith' hoose: seeke shelter, packe,
Falstaffe will learne the honor of the age,
French thrift, you Rogues, my selfe, and skirted Page.
Let Vultures gripe thy guts, for gourd, and Fullam
holds, and high and low beguiles the rich and poore,
Tester ile haue in pouch when thou shalt lacke,
Base Phrygian Turke.
I haue opperations.
Which be humors of reuenge.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Wilt thou reuenge?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: By Welkin, and her Star.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: With wit, or Steele?

lg.l: With both the humors, I;
I will discusse the humour of this Loue to Ford.
And I to Page shall eke vnfold
How Falstaffe (varlet vile)
His Doue will proue; his gold will hold,
And his soft couch defile.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My humor shall not coole; I will incense Ford, to deale with poyson; I will possesse him with yallownesse, for the reuolt of mine is dangerous; that is my true humour.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Thou art the Mars of Malecontents; I second thee; troope on.

div.stage: Exeunt.

div.head: Scoena Quarta:
div.stage: Enter Mistris Quickly, Simple, Iohn Rugby, Doctor Caius, Fenton.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: What, Iohn Rugby, I pray thee goe to the Casement, and see if you can see my Master, Master Doctor Caius comming; if he do (I'faith) and finde any body in the house; here will be an old abusing of Gods patience, and the Kings English.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Ile goe watch.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Goe, and we'll haue a posset for't soone at night, (in faith) at the latter end of a Sea-cole-fire: An honest, willing, kinde fellow, as euer seruant shall come in house withall: & I warrant you, no tel-tale, nor no breedebate: his worst fault is, that he is giuen to prayer; hee is something peeuish that way: but no body but has his fault: but let that passe. Peter Simple, you say your name is?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I, for fault of a better.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: And Master Slender's your Master?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I forsooth.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Do's he not weare a great round Beard, like a Glouers paring-knife?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: No forsooth, he hath but a little wee-face; with a little yellow Beard, a Caine colourd Beard.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: A softtly-sprighted man, is he not?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I forsooth, but he is as tall a man of his hands, as any is betweene this and his head; hee hath fought with a Warrener.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: How say you; oh, I should remember him, do's hee not hold vp his head (as it were?) and strut in his gate?

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: Yes indeede do's he.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Well, heauen send Anne Page, no worse fortune, Tell Master Parson, Euans, I will doe what I can for your Master; Anne is a good girle, and I wish—

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Out alas, here comes my Master.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p:
Wee shall all be shent; Run in here, good young
man, goe into this Closset: hee will not stay long? what Iohn Rugby? Iohn; what Iohn I say? goe Iohn, goe enquire for my Master, I doubt hee be not well, that hee comes not home, (and downe, downe, downe'a, &c.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Vat is you sing? I doe not like des-toyes, pray you goe and vetch me in my Closst, vnboyteene verd; a Box, a greene-a-Box; do intend vat I speake? greene-a-Box.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: I forsooth ile fetch it you: I am glad hee went not in himselfe: if hee had found the yong man he would haue beene horne-mad.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Fe, fe, fe, fe, mai foy, il fait for chando, le man voi a le Court la grand affaires.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Is it this Sir?

lg.l: Ouy mette le au mon pocket, de-peech quickly:
Vere is dat knaue Rugby?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: What Iohn Rugby, Iohn?

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: You are Iohn Rugby, and you are Iacke Rugby; Come, take your Rapier, and come after my heele to the Court.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: 'Tis ready Sir, here in the Porch.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: By my trot, I tarry too long, od's-me: que ay ie oublie dere is some Simples in my Closset, dat I vill not for the varld I shall leaue behinde.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Ay-me, he'll finde the yong man there, and be mad▪

lg.l: O Diable, Diable; vat is in my Closset?
Villaine, La-roone; Rugby, my Rapier.

sp.speaker: Qu,
sp.p: Good Master be content.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Wherefore shall I be content-a?

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: The yong man is an honest man.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: What shall de honest man do in my Closset, here is no honest man dat shall come in my Closset.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: I beseech you be not so flegmaticke; heare the truth of it. He came of an errand to mee, from Parson Hugh.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Vell.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: I forsooth: to desire her to—

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Peace, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Peace-a-your tongue: speake-a-your Tale.

sp.speaker: Si.
sp.p: To desire this honest Gentlewoman (your Maid) to speake a good word to Mistris Anne Page, for my Master in the way of Marriage.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: This is all indeed-la: but ile nere put my finger in the fire, and neede not.

sp.speaker: Ca.
sp.p: Sir Hugh send-a you? Rugby, ballow me some paper: tarry you a littell-a while.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: I am glad hee is so quiet: if hee had bin throughly moued, you should haue heard him so loud, and so melancholly; but notwithstanding man, Ile doe yoe your Master what good I can; and the very yea, and the no is that French Doctor my Master, (I may call him my Master, looke you, for I keepe his house; and I wash, ring, brew, bake, scowre, dresse meate and drinke, make the beds, and doe all my selfe.)

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: 'Tis a great charge to come vnder one bodies hand.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Are you a uis'd o' that? you shall finde it a great charge: and to be vp early, and downe late; but notwithstanding, (to tell you in your eare, I would haue no words of it) my Master himselfe is in loue with Mistris Anne Page; but notwithstanding that I know Ans mind, that's neither heere nor there.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: You, Iack ' Nape; glue-'a this Letter to Sir Hugh, by gar it is a shallenge: I will cut his troat in de Parke, and I will teach a scuruy Iack-a-nape Priest to meddle, or make:— you may be gon: it is not good you tarry here; by gar I will cut all his two stones; by gar, he shall not haue a stone to throw at his dogge.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Alas, he speakes but for his friend.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: It is no matter'a vor dat; do not you tell-a-me dat I shall haue Anne Page for my selfe? by gar, I vill kill de Iacke Priest; and I haue appointed mine Host of de Iarteer to measure our weapon, by gar, I will my selfe haue Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Sir, the maid loues you, and all shall bee well; Wee must giue folkes leaue to prate; what the good ier.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Rugby, come to the Court with me: by gar, if I haue not Anne Page, I shall turne your head out of my dore: follow my heeles, Rugby.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: You shall haue An-fooles head of your owne; No, I know Ans mind for that; neuer a woman in Windsor knowes more of Ans minde then I doe, nor can doe more then I doe with her, I thanke heauen.

sp.speaker: Fenton.
sp.p: Who's with in there, hoa?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Who's there, I troa? Come neere the house I pray you.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: How now (good woman) how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: The better that it pleases your good Worship to aske?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: What newes? how do's pretty Mistris Anne?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: In truth Sir, and shee is pretty, and honest, and gentle, and one that is your friend, I can tell you that by the way, I praise heauen for it.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Shall I doe any good thinkst thou? shall I not loose my suit?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Troth Sir, all is in his hands aboue; but notwithstanding (Master Fenton) Ile be sworne on a booke shee loues you; haue not your Worship a wart aboue your eye?

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Yes marry haue I, what of that?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Well, thereby hangs a tale; good faith, it is such another Nan; (but (I detest) an honest maid as euer broke bread: wee had an howres talke of that wart; I shall neuer laugh but in that maids company, but (indeed) shee is giuen too much to Allicholy and musing; but for you— well— goe too—.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Well, I shall see her to day; hold, there's money for thee. Let mee haue thy voice in my behalfe; if thou seest her before me, commend me.—

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Willi●? I faith that wee will; And I will tell your Worship more of the Wart, the next time we haue confidence, and of other wooers.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Well, fare-well, I am in great haste now.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Fare-well to your Worship; truely an honest
Gentleman: but Anne loues him not, for I know Ans minde as well as another do's, out vpon't, what haue I forgot.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Mistris Page, Mistris Ford, Master Page, Master Ford, Pistoll, Nim, Quickly, Host, Shallow.

sp.speaker: Mi. Page.
sp.p: What, haue I scap'd Loue-letters in the holly-day-time of my beauty, and am I now a subiect for them? let me see.

Aske me no reason why I loue you, for though Loue vse Reason for his precisian, hee admits him not for his Counsailour: you are not young, no more am I: goe to then, there's simpathie: you are merry▪ so am I: ha, ha, then there's more simpathie: you loue sacke, and so doe I: would yout desire better simpathie? Let it suffice thee (Mistris Page) at the least if the Loue of Souldier can suffice, that I loue thee: I will not say pitty mee, 'tis not a Souldier-like phrase; but I say▪ loue me:

lg.l: By me, thine owne true Knight, by day or night:
Or any kinde of light, with all his might,
For thee to fight, Iohn Falstaffe.
What a Herod of Iurie is this? O wicked, wicked world.
One that is well-nye worne to peeces with age
To show himselfe a young Gallant? What an vnwaied

sp.p: Behauiour hath this Flemish drunkard pickt (with The Deuills name) out of my conuersation, that hee dares In this manner assay me? why, hee hath not beene thrice In my Company, what should I say to him? I was then Frugall of my mirth: (heauen forgiue mee,) why ile Exhibit a Bill in the Parliament for the putting downe of men, how shall I be reueng'd on him? for reueng'd I will be? as sure as his guts are made of puddings.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Mistris Page, trust me, I was going to your house.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: And trust me, I was going to you: you looke very ill.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Nay, ile nere beleeue that; I haue to shew to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page
sp.p: 'Faith but you doe in my minde.

sp.speaker: Mis. Fords
sp.p: Well: I doe then; yet I say, I could shew you to the contrary; O Mistris Page, giue mee some counsaile.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: What's the matter, woman?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: O woman; if it were not for one trifling respect, I could come to such honour.

sp.speaker: Mis▪ Page.
sp.p: Hang the trifle (woman) take the honour; what is it? dispence with trifles; what is it?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: If I would but goe to hell, for an eternall moment, or so; I could be knighted.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: What thou liest? Sir Alice Ford? these Knights will hacke, and so thou shouldst not alter the article of thy Gentry.

sp.speaker: Mis▪ Ford.
sp.p: Wee burne day-light; heere, read, read; perceiue how I might be knighted, I shall thinke the worse of fat men, as long as I haue an eye to make difference of mens liking; and yet hee would not sweare: praise womens modesty; and gaue such orderly and welbehaued reproofe to all vncomelinesse, that I would haue sworn his disposition would haue gone to the truth of his words: but they doe no more adhere and keepe place together, then the hundred Psalmes to the tune of Greene-sleeues: What tempest (I troa) threw this Whale, (with so many Tuns of oyle in his belly) a'shoare at Windsor? How shall I be reuenged on him? I thinke the best way were, to entertaine him with hope, till the wicked fire of lust haue melted him in his owne grease. Did you euer heare the like?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
Letter for letter; but that the name of Page and Ford differs; to thy great comfort in this mystery of ill opinions, heer's the twyn-brother of thy Letter; but let thine inherit first, for I protest mine neuer shall: I warrant hee hath a thousand of these Letters, writ
with blancke space for different names (sure more) & these are of the second edition; he wil print them out of doubt, for he cares not what he puts into the presse, when he would put vs two; I had rather be a Giantesse & lye vnder Mount ●elion. Well; I will finde you twentie lascioious Turtles ere one chaste man.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Why this is the very same; the very hand, the very words, what doth he thinke of vs?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Nay I know not; it makes me almost readie to wrangle with mine owne honesty; Ile entertaine my selfe like one that I am not acquainted withall, for sure vnlesse hee know some straine in mee, that I know not my selfe, hee would neuer haue boorded me in this furie.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Boording, call you it? Ile be sure to keepe him aboue decke.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: So will I, if hee come vnder my hatches, Ile neuer to Sea againe. Let's be reueng'd on him; let's appoint him a meeting, giue him a show of comfort in his Suite, and lead him on with a fine baited delay, till hee hath pawn'd his horses to mine Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Nay, I will consent to act any villany against him, that may not sully the charinesse of our honesty; oh that my husband saw this Letter; it would giue eternall food to his iealousie.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Why looke where he comes; and my good man too; hee's as farre from iealousie, as I am from giuing him cause, and that (I hope) is an vnmeasurable distance:

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: You are the happier woman.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Let's consult together against this greasie Knight; Come hither.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well, I hope, it be not so.

lg.l: Hope is a curtall-dog in some affaires;
Sir Iohn affects thy wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Why sir, my wife is not young.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p:
He wooes both high and low, both rich and poore, both young and old, one with another (Ford) he loues the
Gally-mawfry (Ford) perpend.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Loue my wife?

lg.l: With liuer, burning hot: preuent:
Ot goe thou like Sir Acteon he, with
Ring-wood at thy heeles: O, odious is the name.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What name Sir?

lg.l: The horne I say▪ Farewell.
Take heed, haue open eye, for theeues doe foot by night.
Take heed, ere sommer comes, or Cuckoo▪ birds doe sing.
Away sir Corporall Nim.
Beleeue it (Page) he speakes sence.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will be patient; I will finde out this.

sp.speaker: Nim.
sp.p: And this is true; I like not the humor of lying, hee haue wronged mee in some humors; I should haue borne the humour'd Letter to her, but I haue a sword, and it shall bite vpon my necessitie, he loues your wife; There's the sh●●t and the long: My name is Corporall Nim, I speak, and I auouch; 'tis true: my name is Nim, and Falstoffe loues your wife, adieu, I loue not the humour of bread & cheese: adieu.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: The humour of it (quoth'a▪) heere's a fellow frights English out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will seeke out Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I neuer heard such a drawling-affecting rogue▪

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: If I doe finde it: well▪

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I will not beleeue such a Catai●●, though the Priest o'th'Towne commended him for a true man.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: 'Twas a good sensible fellow, well.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: How now Meg?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Whither goe you (George?) harke you.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: How now (sweet Frank) why art thou me▪ lancholy?

lg.l: I melancholy? I am not melancholy:
Get you home, goe.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Faith, thou hast some crochets in thy head, Now, will you goe, Mistris Page?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
Haue with you, you'll come to dinner George▪ Looke who comes yonder; shee shall bee our Messenger
to this paltrie Knight:

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Trust me, I thought on her; shee'll fit it:

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: You are come to see my daughter Anne?

sp.speaker: Qui,
sp.p: I forsooth: and I pray how do's good Mistresse Anne?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Go in with vs and see, wee haue an houres talke with you.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: How now Master Ford?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: You heard what this knaue told me, did you not?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yes, and you heard what the other told me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Doe you thinke there is truth in them?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Hang▪ em slaues: I doe not thinke the Knight would offer it: But these that accuse him in his intent towards our wiues, are a yoake of his discarded men, very rogues, now they be out of seruice▪

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Were they his men?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Marry were they.

lg.l: I like it neuer the better for that,
Do's he lye at the Garter?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I marry do's he: if hee should intend this voyage toward my wife, I would turne her loose to him, and what hee gets more of her, then sharpe words, let it lye on my head.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I doe not misdoubt my wife, but I would be Ioath to turne them together, a man may bee too confident, I would haue nothing lye on my head, I cannot be thus satisfied.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Looke where my ranting-Host of the Garter comes: there is either liquor in his pate, or mony in his purse, when hee lookes so merrily: How now mine Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: How now Bully-Rooke, thou'rt a Gentleman, Caueleiro Iustice, I say.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I follow, (mine Host) I follow, Good-euen, and twenty (good Master Page) Master Page, will you go with vs? we haue sport in hand.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Tell him Caueleiro-Iustice: tell him Bully-Rooke.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Sir, there is a fray to be fought, betweene Sir Huge the Welch Priest, and Caius the French Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Good mine Host o'th'Garter, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What saist thou, my Bully-Rooke?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Will you goe with vs to behold it? My merry Host hath had the measuring of their weapons, and (I thinke) appointed them contrary places: for (beleeue me) I heare the Parson is no Iester▪ harke, I will tell you what our sport shall be.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Hast thou no suit against my Knight? my guest-Caualeire?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: None, I protest, but ile giue you a pottle of burn'd sacke, to giue me recourse to him, and tell him my name is Broome, onely for a iest.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: My hand, (Bully,) thou shalt haue egresse and regresse, (said I well▪) and thy name shall be Broome. It is a merry Knight, will you goe An-heires?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Haue with you mine Host.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I haue heard the French-man hath good skill in his Rapier.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Tut Sir, I could haue told you more. In these times you stand on distance, your Passes, Stoccado's, and I know not what: 'tis the heart (Master Page,) 'tis heere, 'tis heere, I haue seene the time, with my long-sword, I would haue made you fowre tall fellowes skippe like Rattes.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Heere boyes, heere, heere, shall we wag?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Haue with you, I had rather heare them scold, then fight.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Though Page be a secure foole, and stands so firmely on his wiues frailty: yet, I cannot put-off my opinion so easily, she was in his company at Pages house, and what they made there, I know not. Well, I will looke further into't, and I haue a disguise, to sound Falstaffe, if I finde her honest, I loose not my labour, if shee be otherwise, 'tis labour well bestowed.

div.head: Scoena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Falstaffe, Pistoll, Robin, Quickly, Bardolffe, Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I will not lend thee a penny.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Why then the world's mine Oyster, which I, with sword will open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Not a penny, I haue beene content (Sir,) you should lay my countenance to pawne; I haue granted vpon my good friends for three Repreeues for, and your Coach▪ fellow Nim, or else you had look'd through the grate, like a Geminy of Baboones: I am damn'd in hell, for swearing to Gentlemen my friends, you were good Souldiers, and tall-fellowes. And when Mistresse Briget lost the handle of her Fan, I took't vpon mine honour thou hadst it not.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: Didst not thou share? hadst thou not fifteene pence?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Reason, you roague, reason; thinkst thou Ile endanger my soule, gratis? at a word, hang no more about mee, I am no gibbet for you: goe, a short knife, and a throng, to your Mannor of Pickt-hatch; goe, you'll not beare a Letter for mee you roague? you stand vpon your honour: why, (thou vnconfinable basenesse) it is as much as I can doe to keepe the termes of my honour precise; I, I, I my selfe sometimes, leauing the feare of heauen on the left hand, and hiding mine honor in my necessity, am faine to shuffle: to hedge, and to lurch, and yet, you Rogue, will en-sconce your raggs; your Cat-a-Mountaine-lookes, your red-lattice phrases, & your boldbeatingoathes, vnder the shelter of your honor? you will not doe it? you?

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: I doe relent: what would thou more of man?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Sir, here's a woman would speake with you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Let her approach.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Giue your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good-morrow, good-wife.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Not so, and't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good, maid then.

lg.l: Ile be sworne.
As my mother was the first houre I was borne.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I doe beleeue the swearer; what with me?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Shall I vouch-safe your worship a word, or two?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Two thousand (faire woman) and ile vouchsafe thee the hearing.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: There is one Mistresse Ford, (Sir) I pray come a little neerer this waies; I my selfe dwell with Master Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, on; Mistris Ford, you say.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Your worship saies very true; I pray your worship come a little neerer this waies.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I warrant thee, no-bodie heares; mine owne people, mine owne people.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Are they so? heauen-blesse them, and make them his Seruants.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well; Mistresse Ford, what of her?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Why, Sir; shee's a good creature; Lord, Lord your Worship's a wanton: well, heauen forgiue you, and all of vs, I pray—

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mistresse Ford, come, Mistresse Ford.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Marry this is the short, and the long of it; you haue brought her into such a Canaries, as 'tis wonderfull; the best Courtier of them all (when the Court lay at Windsor) could neuer haue brought her to such a Canarie: yet there has beene Knights, and Lords, and Gentlemen, with their Coaches; I warrant you Coach after Coach, letter after letter, gift aftee gift, smelling so sweetly; all Muske, and so rushling, I warrant you, in silke and golde, and in such alligant tearmes, and in such wine and suger of the best, and the fairest, that would haue wonne any womans heart: and I warrant you, they could neuer get an eye-winke of her: I had my selfe twentie Angels giuen me this morning, but I defie all Angels in
any such sort, as they say) but in the way of honesty: and I warrant you, they could neuer get her so much as sippe on a cup with the prowdest of them all, and yet there has beene Earles; nay, (which is more) Pentioners, but I warrant you all is one with her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But what saies shee to mee? bee briefe my good shee- Mercurie.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Marry, she hath receiu'd your Letter; for the which she thankes you a thousand times; and shee giues you to notifie, that her husband will be absence from his house, betweene ten and eleuen.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ten, and eleuen.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: I, forsooth; and then you may come and see the picture (she sayes) that you wot of; Master Ford her husband will be from home: alas, the sweet woman leads an ill life with him; hee's a very iealousie-man; shee leades a vere framepold life with him, (good heart.)

lg.l: Ten, and eleuen.
Woman, commend me to her, I will not faile her.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Why, you say well: But I haue another messenger to your worship: Mistresse Page hath her heartie commendations to you to; and let me tell you in your eare, shee's as fartuous a ciuill modest wife, and one (I tell you) that will not misse you morning nor euening prayer, as any is in Windsor, who ere be the other: and shee bade mee tell your worship, that her husband is seldome from home, but shee hopes there will come a time. I neuer knew a woman so doate vpon a man; surely I thinke you haue charmes, la: yes in truth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Not I, I assure thee; setting the attraction of my good parts aside, I haue no other charmes.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Blessing on your heart for't:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: But I pray thee tell me this; has Fords wife, and Pages wise acquainted each other, how they loue me?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
That were a iest indeed they haue not so little grace I hope, that were a tricke indeed: But Mistis Page would desire you to send her your little Page of all loues; her husband has a maruellous infection to the little Page;
and truely Master Page is an honest man; neuer a wife in Windsor leades a better life then she do's; do what shee will, say what she will, take all, pay all, goe to bed when shee list, rise when she list, all is as she will; and truly she deserues it; for if there be a kinde woman in Windsor, shee is one; you must send her your Page, no remedie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Why, I will.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Nay, but doe so then, and looke you, hee may come and goe betweene you both; and in any case haue a nay-word, that you may know one anothers minde, and the Boy neuer heede to vnderstand any thing; for 'tis not good that children should know any wickednes; old folkes you know, haue discretion, as they say, and know the world.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Farethee-well, commend mee to them both, there's my purse, I am yet thy debter; Boy, goe along with this woman, this newes distracts me.

lg.l: This Puncke is one of Cupids Carriers,
Clap no more sailes, pursue▪ vp with your fights:
Giue fire; she is my prize, or Ocean whelme all.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Saist thou so (old Iacke) goe thy waies Ile make more of thy old body then I haue done: will they yet looke after thee? wilt thou after the expence of so much money, be now a gainer? good Body, I thanke thee; let them say 'tis grossely done, so it bee fairely done, no matter.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir Iohn, there's one Master Broome below would faine speake with you, and be acquainted with you; and hath sent your worship a mornings draught of Sacke.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Broome is his name?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Call him in: such Broomes are welcome to me, that that ore'flowes such liquor; ah ha, Mistresse Ford and Mistresse Page, haue I encompass'd you? goe to, via.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: ‛ Blesse you sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And you sir; would you speake with me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I make bold, to presse, with so little preparation vpon you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You'r welcome, what's you●●ill? giue vs leaue Drawer.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Sir, I am a Gentleman that haue spent much, my name is Broome.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good Master Broome, I desire more acquaintance of you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Good Sir Iohn, I sue for yours; not to charge you, for I must let you vnderstand, I thinke my selfe in better plight for a Lender, then you are; the which hath something emboldned mee to this vnseason'd intrusion: for they say, if money goe before, all waies doe lye open.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Money is a good Souldier (Sir) and will on.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Troth, and I haue a bag of money heere troubles me; if you will helpe to beare it (Sir Iohn) take all, or halfe for easing me of the carriage:

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Sir, I know not how I may deserue to bee your Porter.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will tell you Sir, if you will giue mee the hearing.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Speake (good Master Broome) I shall be glad to be your Seruant.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Sir, I heare you are a Scholler; (I will be briefe with you) and you haue beene a man long knowne to me, though I had neuer so good meanes as desire, to make my selfe acquainted with you. I shall discouer a thing to you, wherein I must very much lay open mine own imperfection: but (good Sir Iohn) as you haue one eye vpon my follies, as you heare them vnfolded, turne another into the Register of your owne, that I may passe with a reproofe the easier, sith you your selfe know how easie it is to be such an offender.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Very well Sir, proceed:

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: There is a Gentlewoman in this Towne, her husbands name is Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well Sir.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
I haue long lou'd her, and I protest to you, bestowed much on her; followed her with a doating obseruance;
Ingross'd opportunities to meete her▪ free'd euery slight occasion that could but nigardly giue mee sight of her▪ not onely brought many presents to giue her, but haue giuen largely to many, to know what she would haue giuen briefly, I haue pursu'd her, as Loue hath pursud mee, which hath beene on the wing of all occasions; but whatsoeuer I haue merited, either in my minde, or in my meanes, meede I am sure I haue receiued none, vnlesse Experience be a Iewell, that I haue purchased at an infinite rate, and that hath taught me to say this.

lg.l: `` Loue like a shadow flies, when substance Loue pursues,
`` Pursuing that that flies, and flying what pursues▪

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Haue you receiu'd no promise of satisfaction at her hands?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Haue you importun'd her to such a purpose?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Neuer.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Of what qualitie was your loue then?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Like a faire house, built on another mans ground, so that I haue lost my edifice, by mistaking the place where I erected it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: To what purpose haue you vnfolded this to me?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: When I haue told you that, I haue told you all: Some say, that though shee appeare honest to mee, yet in other places shee enlargeth hir mirth so farre, that there is shrewd construction made of her. Now (Sir Iohn) here is the heart of my purpose: you are a Gentleman of excellent breeding, admirable discourse, of great admittance, authenticke in your place and person, generally allow'd for your many warlike, court-like, and learned preparations.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: O Sir.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Beleeue it, for you know it: there is money, spend it, spend it, spend more; spend all I haue, onely giue me so much of your time in exchange of it, as to lay an amiable siege to the honesty of this Fords wife: vse your Art of
wooing; win her to consent to you; if any man may, you may as soone as any.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Would it apply well to the vehemency of your affection that I should win what you would enioy? Methinkes you prescribe to your selfe very preposterously.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: O, vnderstand my drift; she dwells so securely on the excellency of her honor, that the folly of my soule dares not present it selfe; she is too bright to be look'd against. Now, could I come to her with any detection in my hand; my desires had instance and argument to commend themselues, I could driue her then from the ward of her purity, her reputation, her marriage vow, and a thousand other her defences, which now are too-too strongly embattaild against me; what say you too't, Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Master Broome, I will first make bold with your mony, next, giue me your hand; and last, as I am a Gentleman, you shall, if you will, enioy Fords wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: O good Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I say you shall.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Want no money (Sir Iohn) you shall want none.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Want no Mistresse Ford (Master Broome) you shall want none; I shall be with her (I may tell you) by her own appointment, euen as you came in to me, her assistant, or goe betweene, parted from me; I say I shall be with her betweene ten and eleuen, for at that time the iealious rascallyknaue her husband will be forth; come you to me at night, you shall know how I speed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I am blest in your acquaintance; do you know Ford Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Hang him (poore Cuckoldly knaue) I know him not: yet I wrong him to call him poore; They say the iealous wittolly-knaue hath masses of money, for the which his wife seemes to me well-fauourd: I will vse her as the key of the Cuckoldly-rogues Coffer, & ther's my haruest▪ home.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I would you knew Ford, sir, that you might auoid him, if you saw him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Hang him, mechanicall-salt-butter rogue; I will stare him out of his wits; I will awe-him with my cudgell: it
shall hang like a Meteor ore the Cuckolds horns: Master Broome, thou shalt know, I will predominate ouer the pezant, and thou shalt lye with his wife▪ Come to me soone at night: Ford's a knaue, and I will aggrauate his stile: thou (Master Broome) shalt know him for knaue, and Cuckold. Come to me soone at night.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What a damn'd Epicurian-Rascall is this? my heart is ready to cracke with impatience: who saies this is improuident iealousie? my wife hath sent to him, the howre is fixt, the match is made; would any man haue thought this? see the hell of hauing a faire woman: my bed shall be abus'd, my Coffers ransack'd, my reputation gnawne at, and I shall not onely receiue this villanous wrong, but stand vnder the adoption of abhominable termes, and by him that does me this wrong: Termes, names: Amaimon sounds well; Lucifer, well; Barbason, wel; yet they are Diuels additions, the names of fiends: But Cuckold, Wittoll, Cuckold▪ the Diuell himselfe hath not such a name. Page is an Asse, a secure Asse; hee will trust his wife, hee will not bee iealous; I will rather trust a Fleming with my butter, Person Hugh the Welshman with my Cheese, an Irish man with my Aqua-vitae-bottle, or a Theefe to walke my ambling gelding, then my wife with her selfe. Then she plots, then shee rumiuates▪ then shee deuises; and what they thinke in their hearts they may effect; they will breake their hearts but they will effect. Heauen bee prais'd for my iealousie: eleuen o'clocke the howre, I will preuent this, detect my wife, bee reueng'd on Falstaffe, and laugh at Page. I will about it, beter three houres too soone, then a mynute too late: fie, fie, fie: Cuckold, Cuckold, Cuckold.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Caius, Rugby, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Iacke Rugby.

sp.speaker: Ru.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Vat lothe clocke▪ Iack.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: 'Tis past the howre (Sir) that Sir Hugh promis'd to meet.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: By gar, he has saue his soule, dat he is no-come: hee has pray his Pible well, dat hee is no-come, by gar (lack Rugby) he is dead already, if he be come.

sp.speaker: Rug
sp.p: Hee is wise Sir; hee knew your worship would kill him if he came.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: By gar, de herring is no dead, so as I vill kill him▪ take your Rapier, (Iacke) I vill tell you how I vill kill him.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: Alas sir, I cannot fence.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Villanie, take your Rapier.

sp.speaker: Rug.
sp.p: For beare, heer's company.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: ‛ Blesse thee, bully-Doctor.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: 'Saue you Master Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Now good Master Doctor.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: ‛ Giue you good morrow, sir.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Vat be all you one, two, tree, fowre, come for?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: To see thee fight, to see thee foigne, to see thee trauerse, to see thee he●re, to see thee there, to see thee passe thy puncto, thy stocke, thy reuerse, thy distance, thy montant: Is hee dead, my Ethiopian? Is he dead, my Francisco? ha Bully? what saies my Esculapius? my Gallen? my heart of Elder? ha? is he dead bully-Stale? is he dead?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar, he is de Coward Iack-Priest of de vorld: he is not show his face.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thou art a Castalion-king Vrinall; Hector of Greece (my Boy)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I pray you beare witnesse, that mee haue stay, sixe or seuen, two tree howres for him, and hee is no-come.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: He is the wiserman (Master Doctor) he is a curer of soules, and you a curer of bodies; if you should fight, you goe against the haire of your professions▪ is it not true, Master Page?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Master Shallow; you haue your selfe beene a great
great fighter, though now a man of peace.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Body-kins M. Page, though I now be old, and of the peace; if I see a sword out, my finger itches to make one; though wee are Iustices, and Doctors, and Church-men (Master Page) wee haue some salt of our youth 〈◊〉 vs, we are the sons of women (Master Page.)

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: 'Tis true, Mister Shallow.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: It will be found so, (M. Page) M. Doctor Caius, I am come to fetch you home, I am sworn of the peace you haue show'd your selfe a wise Physician, and Sir Hugh hath showne himselfe a wise and patient Churchman; you must goe with me, M. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Pardon, Guest-Iustice; a Mounseur Mocke-water.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Mock-vater? vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Mock-water, in our English tongue, is Valour (Bully.)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar, then I haue as much Mock-vater as de Englishman; scuruy-lade dog-Priest▪ by gar, mee vill his eares.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: He will Clapper claw thee tightly (Bully.)

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Clapper de claw? vat is dat?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: That is, he will make thee amends.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar, me doe looke he shall clapper-de-claw me, for by-gar me vill haue it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: And I will prouoke him to't, or let him wag:

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Me tanck you for dat.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: And moreouer, (Bully) but first, Master Ghuest, and M. Page, and eeke Cauale●ro Slender, goe you through the Towneto Frogmore.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Sir Hugh is there, is he?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: He is there, see what humor hee is in; and I will bring the Doctor about by the Fields; will it doe well?

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Wee will doe it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Adieu, good Master Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By-gar, me vill kill de Priest, for he speake for a Iack-an-Ape to Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Let him die; sheath thy impatience, throw cold
water on thy Choller; goe about the fields with me through Frogmore, I will bring thee where Mistris Anne Page is, at a Farm-house a Feasting; and thou shalt wooe her, Cride-game, said I well?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By-gar, me danck you vor dat; by gar I loue you, and I shall procure'a you de good Guest; de Earle, de Knight, de Lords▪ de Gentlemen, my patients.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: For the which, I will be thy aduersary toward Anne Page, said. I well?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By-gar, 'tis good, vell said.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Let vs wag then.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Come at my heeles, Iack Rugby.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Euans, Simple, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host, Caius, Rugby.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: I pray you now, good Master Slenders seruingman and friend Simple by your name; which way haue you look'd for Master Caius, that calls himselfe Doctor of Phisicke.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Marry Sir, the pittie-ward, the Parke-ward, euery way, olde Windsor way, and euery way but the Towne-way.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I most fehemently desire you, you will looke that way.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
‛ Plesse my soule: how full of Chollors I am and trempling of minde; I shall be glad if hee haue deceiued me: how melancholies I am? I will knog his Vrinalls about his knaues costard, when I haue good oportunities for the orke▪ Plesse my soule. To shallow Riuers to whose falls; melodious Birds sing Madrigalls: There will wee make our Peds of Roses: and a thousand fragrant posies. To shallow: ' Mercie on mee, I haue a great dispositions to cry: Melodious birds sing Madrigalls:— When as I sat in Pabilon:
and a thousand vagram Posies. To shallow, &c.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Yonder he is comming, this ●ay Sir Hugh.

lg.l: Hee's welcome: To shallow Riuers, in whose fals:
Heauen prosper the right: what weapons is he?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: No weapons, Sir; there comes my master, Master Shallow, and another Gentleman; from Frogmore, ouer the stile, this way.

sp.speaker: Euen.
sp.p: Pray you giue me my gowne, or else keepe it in your armes.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: How now Master Parson? good morrow good Sir Hugh, keepe a Gamester from the dice, and a good Studient from his booke, and it is wonderfull.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ah sweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: 'Saue you, good Sir Hugh.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: ▪ Pleasse you from his mercy-sake, all of you.

lg.l: What? the Sword, and the Word?
Doe you study them both Master Parson?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And youthfull still, in your doublet and hose, this raw-rumaticke day?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: There is reasons, and causes for it?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Wee are come to you, to doe a good office, Master Parson.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Fery-well, what is it?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yonder is a most reuerend Gentleman; who (be-like) hauing receiued wrong by some person, is at most odds with his owne grauity and patience, that euer you saw.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I haue liued foure-score yeeres, and vpward; I neuer heard a man of his place, grauity, and learning, so wide of his owne respect.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: I thinke you know him; Master Doctor Caius the renowned French Physician.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Got's will, and his passion of my heart, I had as liefe you would tell me of a messe of poriedge.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p:
Hee has no more knowledge in Hibocrates and Galen, and hee is a knaue besides: a cowardly knaue, as
you would desires to acquainted withall▪

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I warrant you, hee's the man should fight with him.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: O sweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: It appeares so by his weapons; keepe them a sunder, here comes Doctor Caius.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Nay good Master Parson, keepe your weapon.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: So doe you, good Master Doctor.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Disarme them, and let them question; let them keepe their limbs whole, and hacke our English.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I pray you let-a-mee speake a word with your eare; vherefore vill you not meet a me?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I Pray you vse your patience in good time.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: By gar, you are de Coward: de Iacke dog: Iohn Ape.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Pray you let vs not be laughing-stocks to other mens humors; I desire you in friendship, and I will one way or other make you amends; I will knog your Vrinal about your knaues Cogs-combe.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Diable; Iack Rugby: mine Host de Iarteer; haue I not stay for him, to kill him? haue I not at de place I did appoint?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: As I am a Christians soule, now looke you; this is the place appointed, ile be iudgement by mine Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Peace, I say, Gallia and Gaule, French and Welch, Soule-Curer, and Body-Curer.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I, dat is very good, excellant.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Peace, I say, heare mine Host of the Garter, Am I politicke? Am I subtle? Am I a Machiuell? Shall loose my Doctor? No, he giues me the Potions and the Motions. Shall I loose my Parson? my Priest? my Sir Hugh? No, hee giues me the Prouerbes, and the No verbes. Giue me thy hand (Celestiall) so; Boyes of Art, I haue deceiu'd you both; I haue directed you to wrong places; your hearts are mighty, your skinnes are whole, and let burn'd Sacke be the issue; Come▪ lay their swords to pawne; Follow me, Lad of peace, follow, follow, follow▪

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Trust me, a mad Host: follow Gentlemen, follow.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: O sweet Anne Page.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Ha'do I perceiue dat? Haue you make-a-de. sot of vs, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: This is well, he has made vs his vlowting-stog: I desire you that we may be friends; and let vs knog our praines together to be reuenge on this same scall scuruycogging-companion the Host of the Garter.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar, with all my heart; he promise to bring mee where is Anne Page, by gar he deceiue me too.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Well, I will smite his noddles; pray you follow.

div.head: Scoena Secunda.
div.stage: Mist. Page, Robin, Ford, Page, Shallow, Slender, Host, Euans, Caius.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Nay keepe your way (little Gallant) you were wont to be a follower; but now you are a Leader: whether had you rather lead mine eyes, or eye your masters heeles?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I had rather (forsooth, goe before you like a man▪ Courtier. then follow him like a dwarfe.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: O you are a flattering boy, now I see you'l be a

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well met mistris Page, whether go you.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Truly Sir, to see your wife, is she at home?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I, and as idle as she may hang together for want of companie; I thinke if your husbands were dead, you two would marry.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Be sure of that, two other husbands.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Where had you this pretty weather-cocke?

sp.speaker: Mist. Pa.
sp.p: I cannot tell what (the dickens) his name is my husband had him of, what doe you cal your Knights name sirrah?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falstaffe.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falstafe.

sp.speaker: M. P.
sp.p: He, he, I can neuer hit on's name; there is such aleague between my goodman, and he; is your Wife at home indeed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Indeed she is.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: By your leaue sir, I am sicke till I see her.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Has Page any braines▪ Hath he any eies? Hath he any thinking? Sure they sleepe, hee hath no vse of them: why this boy will carrie a letter twentie mile as easie, as a Canon will shoot point-blanke twelue score: hee peeces out his wiues inclination, hee giues her folly motion and aduantage: and now she's going to my wife, and Falstaffes boy with her; A man may heare this showre sing in the winde; and Falstaffes boy with her: good plots, they are laide, and our reuolted wiues share damnation together. Well, I will take him, then torture my wife, plucke the borrowed vaile of modestie from the so seeming Mistris Page, divulge Page himselfe for a secure and wilfull Acteon, and to these violent proceedings all my neighbors shall cry aime. The clocke giues me my Qu, and my assurance bids me search, there I shall finde Falstaffe: I shall be rather praisd for this, then mock'd, for it is as possitiue, as the earth is firme, that Falstaffe is there: I will go.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Page, &c. Well met Master Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Trust me, a good knotte; I haue good cheere at home, and I pray you all go with me.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: I must excuse my selfe Master Ford.

lg.l: And so must I Sir,
We haue appointed to dine with Mistris Anne,
And I would not breake with her for more mony
Then ile speake of.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: We haue linger'd about a match betweene Anne Page, and my cozen Slender, and this day wee shall haue our answer.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I hope I haue your good will Father Page.

sp.speaker: Page
sp.p: You haue Master Slender, I stand wholly for you, But my wife (Master Doctor) is for you altogether.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: I be-gar, and de Maid is loue-a me: my nursh-aQuickly tell me so mush.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
What say you to young Master Fenton? He capers, he dances, he has cies of youth▪ he writes verses, he speakes
holliday, he smels Aprill and May, he will carry't, hee will carry't, 'tis in his buttons, he will carry't.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Not by my consent I promise you. The Gentleman is of no hauing, he kept companie with the wilde Prince, & Pointz: hee is of too high a Region, hee knows too much: no, hee shall not knit a knot in his fortunes, with the finger of my substance, if he takes her, let him take her simply; the wealth I haue waits on my consent, and my consent goes not that way:

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I beseech you heartily, some of you goe home with me to dinner; besides your cheere you shall haue sport, I will shew you a monster; Master Doctor, you shall goe, so shall your Master Page, and you Sir Hugh.

lg.l: Well, fare you well:
We shall haue the freer woing at Master Pages.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Go home Iohn Rugby, I come anon.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Farwell my hearts, I will to my honest Knight Falstaffe, and drinke Canarie with him.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I thinke I shall drinke in Pipe-wine first with him, ile make him dance. Will you go, Gentles?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Haue with you, to see this Monster.

div.head: Scoena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Master Ford. Master Page, Seruants, Robin, Falstaffe. Ford, Page, Caius, Euans.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: What Iohn, what Robert.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Quickly quickly; Is the Buck-basket—

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: I warrant. What Robin I say.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Come, come, come.

sp.speaker: Mi Ford.
sp.p: Heere, set it downe.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p:
Giue your men the charge, wee must be briefe, be ready here hard by in the Brew house, and when I sodainly call you, come forth, and (without any pause, or staggering) take this basket on your shoulders; that done trudge with it in all hast, and carry it among the Whitsters
in Dotchet Mead, and there empty it in the muddie ditch, close by the Thames side.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: You will do it?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: I ha told them ouer and ouer, they lacke no direction. Begone, and come when you are call'd.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Here comes little Robin.

sp.speaker: Mis Ford.
sp.p: How now my Eyas Musket, what newes with you?

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: My M. Sir Iohn is come in at the backe doore Mist. Ford, and requests your company.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: You little lack-a-lent, haue you bin true to vs.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: I, ile be sworne; my Master knowes not of your being heere: and hath threatned to put mee into euerlasting liberty, if I tell you of it; for he sweares he'll turne me away.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Thou'rt a good boy; this secrecy of thine shall be a Tailor to thee, and shall make thee a new doublet and hose. Ile go hide me.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Do so, go tell thy Master, I am alone; Mistris Page, remember you your Qu.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: I warrant thee, if I do not act it, hisse me.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford
sp.p: Go too then; we'l vse this vnwholsome humidity, this grosse-warry Pumpion, we'll teach him to know Turtles from Iayes.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Haue I caught thee, my heauenly Iewell? Why now let me die, for I haue liu'd long enough; This is the period of ambition; O this blessed houre.

sp.speaker: Mis▪ Ford.
sp.p: O sweet Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mistris Ford, I cannot cog, I cannot prate (Master Ford) now shall I sinne in my wish; I would thy Husband were dead, ile speake it before the best Lord, I would make thee my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mis Ford.
sp.p: I your Lady Sir Iohn? Alas, I should be a pittifull Lady.

sp.speaker: Fal▪
sp.p: Let the Court of France shew mee such another; I see how thine eye would emulate the Diamond; Thou hast the right arched-beauty of the brow, that becomes the Ship-tyre, the Tyre-valiant, or any Tire of Venetian admittance.

lg.l: A plaine Kerchiefe, Sir Iohn.
My browes become nothing else, nor that well neither.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thou art a tyrant to say so: thou wouldst make an absolute Courtier, and the firme fixture of thy foote, would giue an excellent motion to thy gate, in a semi-circled Farthingale. I see what thou wert if Fortune thy foe, were not Noture thy friend: Come, thou canst not hide it.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Beleeue me, ther's no such thing in me.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What made me loue thee? Let that perswade thee: Ther's something extraordinary in thee. Come I cannot cog, and say thou art this and that, like a manie of thess lisping hauthorne buds, that come like women in mens apparrell, and smell like. Bucklers-berry in simple time: I cannot, but I loue thee, none but thee; and thou deseru'st it.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Do not betray me sir, I feare you loue M. Page▪

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Thou mightst as well say, I loue to walke by the Counter-gate, which is a hatefull to me, as the reeke of a Lime-kill.

lg.l: Well, heauen knowes how I loue you,
And you shall one day finde it.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Keepe in that minde, Ile deserue it.

lg.l: Nay, I must tell you, so you doe;
Or else I could not be in that minde.

sp.speaker: Rob.
sp.p: Mistris Ford, Mistris Ford, heere's Mistris Page at the doore, sweating, and blowing, and looking wildly, and would needs speake with you presently.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: She shall not see me, I will ensconce mee behinde the Arras.

lg.l: Pray you doe so, she's a very tatling woman.
Whats the matter? How now?
O mistris Ford what haue you done?
You'r sham'd, y'are ouerthrowne, y'are vndone for euer.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: What's the matter, good mistris Page?

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: O weladay, mist. Ford, hauing and honestman to your husband, to giue him such cause of suspition.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: What cause of suspition?

lg.l: What cause of suspition? Out vpon you:
How am I mistooke in you?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Why (alas) what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Your husband's comming hether (Woman) with all the Officers in Windsor, to search for a Gentleman, that hee sayes is heere now in the house, by your consent to take an ill aduantage of his absence, you are vndone.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: 'Tis not, so, I hope.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Pray heauen it be not so, that you haue such a man heere: but 'tis most certaine your husband's comming, with halfe Windsor at his heeles, to serch for such a one, I come before to tell you, if you know your selfe cleere, why I am glad of it, but if you haue a friend here, conuey, conuey him out. Be not amaz'd, call all your senses to you, defend your reputation, or bid farwell to your good life for euer.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: What shall I doe? There is a Gentleman my deere friend, and I feare not mine owne shame so much, as his perill. I had rather then a thousand pound he were out of the house.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: For shame, neuer stand (you had rather, you had rather) your husband's heere at hand, bethinke you of some conueyance: in the house you cannot bide him. Oh, how haue you deceiu'd me? Looke, heere is a basket, if hee be of any reasonable stature, hee may creepe in heere, and throw fowle linnen vpon him, as if it were going to bucking; Or it is whiting time, send him by your two men to Datchet-Meade.

sp.speaker: M. Ford
sp.p: He's too big to go in there, what shall I doe?

lg.l: Let me see't, let me see't, O let me see't:
Ile ●n ile in, follow your friends counsell, ile in.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: What Sir Iohn Falstaffe? Are these your Letters Knight?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I loue thee, helpe mee away: let me creepe in heere: Ile neuer—

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Helpe to couer your Master (Boy:) Call your men (Mist. Ford.) You dissembling Knight.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: What Iohn Rugby, Iohn; Goe, take vp these cloathes heere, quickly: Wher's the Cowle-staffe? Looke how you drumble? Carry them to the Landresse in Datchet meade: quickly▪ come.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: 'Pray you come neere; if I suspect without cause, Why then make sport at me, then let me be your iest, I deserue it: How now? Whether beare you this?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: To the Landresse forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Why, what haue you to doe whether they beare it? You were best meddle with buck-washing.

sp.speaker: Ford.

lg.l: Bucke? I would I could wash my selfe of the Buck:
Bucke, bucke, bucke, I bucke; I warrant you Bucke,
And of the season too, it shall appeare.

sp.p: Gentlemen, I haue dream'd to night, ile tell you my dreame, heere, heere, heere bee my keyes, ascend my Chambers, search, seeke, finde out: ile warrant wee'le vnkennell the Fox. Let mee stop this way first: so, now vncape.

lg.l: Good master Ford, be contented:
You wrong your selfe too much.
True (master Page) vp Gentlemen,
You shall see sport anon:
Follow me Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: This is fery fantasticall humors and iealousies.

lg.l: By gar, 'tis no-the fashion of France:
It is not iealous in France.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Nay follow him (Gentlemen) see the yssue of his search.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Is there not a double excellency in this?

lg.l: I know not which pleases me better,
That my husband is deceiued, or Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: What a taking was he in, when your husband askt who was in the basket?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: I am halfe affraid hee will haue neede of washing, so throwing him into the water, will doe him a benefit.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Hang him dishonest rascall: I would all of the same straine, were in the same distresse.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: I thinke my husband hath some speciall suspition of Falstafs being heere: for I neuer saw him so grosse in his iealousie till now.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: I will lay a plot to try that, and wee will yet haue more trickes with Falstaffe; his dissolute disease will scarse obey this medicne.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Shall we send that foolishion Carion, Mistris Quickly to him, and excuse his throwing into the water, and giue him another hope, to betray him to another punishment?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Wee will doe it; let him be sent for to morrow eight a clocke to haue amends.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I cannot finde him; may be the knaue bragg'd of that he could not compasse▪

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Heard you that?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: You vse me well, M Ford? Doe you?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I, I doe so.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Heauen make you better then your thoughts

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: You doe your selfe mighty wrong (M. Ford)

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I, I; I must beare it.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: If there be any pody in the house, and in the chambers, and in the coffers, and in the presses; heauen forgiue my sinnes at the day of iudgement.

sp.speaker: Caius.
sp.p: Be-gar, nor I too: there is no bodies.
