sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Fy, fy, M Ford, are you not asham'd? What spirit, what diuell suggests this imagination? I would not ha your distemper in this kind, for the welth of Windsor castle.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: 'Tis my fault (M. Page) I suffer for it.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: You suffer for a pad conscience; your wife is as honest a o'mans, as I will desires among fiue thousand, and fiue hundred too.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: By gar, I see 'tis an honest woman.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well, I promisd you a dinner, come, come, walke in the Parke, I pray you pardon me: I will hereafter make knowne to you why I haue done this. Come wife, come Mist Page, I pray you pardon me. Pray hartly pardon me.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Let's go in Gentlemen, but (trust me) we'l mocke
him; I doe inuite you to morrow morning to my house to breakefast: after we'll a Birding together, I haue a fine Hawke for the bush. Shall it be so:

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Any thing.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: If there is one, I shall make two in the Companie.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: If there be one, or two, I shall make-a-theturd.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Pray you goe, M. Page.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: I pray you now remembrance to morrow on the lowsie knaue, mine Host.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Dat is good by gar, withall my heart.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: A lowsie knaue, to haue his gibes, and his mockeries.

div.head: Scoena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Fenton, Anne Page, Shallow, Slender, Quickly, Page, Mist. Page.

lg.l: I see I cannot get thy Fathers loue,
Therefore no more turne me to him (sweet Nan.)

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Alas, how then?

lg.l: Why thou must be thy selfe.
He doth obiect, I am too great of birth,
And that my state being gall'd with my expence,
I seeke to heale it onely by his wealth.
Besides these, other barres he layes before me,
My Riots past, my wilde Societies,
And tels me 'tis a thing impossible
I should loue thee, but as a property.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: May be he tels you true.

lg.l: No, heauen so speed me in my time to come,
Albeit I will confesse, thy Fathers wealth
Was the first motiue that I woo'd thee (Anne:)
Yet wooing thee, I found thee of more valew
Then stamps in Gold, or summes in sealed bagges●
And 'tis the very riches of thy selfe,
That now I ayme at.
Gentle M. Fenton.
Yet seeke my Fathers loue, still seeke it sir,
If opportunity and humblest suite
Cannot attaine it, why then harke you hither.
Breake their talke Mistris Quickly,
My Kinsman shall speake for himselfe.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Ile make a shaft or a bolt on't, slid, tis but venturing.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Be not dismaid.

lg.l: No, she shall not dismay me▪
I care not for that, but that I am affeard.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Hark ye, Master Slender would speake a word with you

lg.l: I come to him. This is my Fathers choice.
O what a world of vilde-ill-fauour'd faults
Lookes handsome in three hundred pounds a yeare?
And how do's god Master Fenton?
Pray you a word with you.
Shee's comming; to her Coz:
O boy, thou hadst a father,

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I had a father (Mistris Anne) my vncle can tel you good iests of him; pray you Vncle, tel Mistris Anne the iest how my Father stole two Geese out of a Pen, good Vnckle.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Mistris Anne, my Cozen loues you.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I that I doe, as well as I loue any woman in Glocestershire.

sp.speaker: Shal
sp.p: He will maintaine you like a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I that I will, come cut and long-taile, vnder the degree of a Squire.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Hee will make you a handred and fiftie pounds ioynture.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Good Master Shallow let him woe for himselfe.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: Marry I thanke you for it, I thanke you for that good comfort: she cals you (Coz) ile leaue you.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Now Master Slender.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Now good Mistris Anne.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: What is your will?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: My will? Odd's-hart-lings, that's a prettie iest indeed: I ne're made my Will yet (I thanke Heauen:) I am not such a sickely creature, I giue Heauen praise.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: I meane (M. Sender) what would you with me?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Truely, for mine owne part, I would little or nothing with you: your father and vncle hath made motions if it be my lucke, so; if not, happy man be his dole, they can tell you how things goe, better then I can: you may, your father, heere he comes.

lg.l: Now Master Slender; Loue him daughter Anne.
Why how now? What does Master Fenton here?
You wrong me Sir, thus still to haunt my house.
I told you Sir, my daughter is disposd of.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Nay Master Page, be not impatient.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Good Master Fenton. come not to my child.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: She is no match for you.

sp.speaker: Fen.
sp.p: Sir, will you heare me?

lg.l: No, good Master Fenton.
Come M. Shallow: Come sonne Slender, in;
Knowing my minde, vou wrong me (M. Fenton.)

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Speake to Mistris Page.

lg.l: Good Mistris Page, for that I loue your daughter
In such a righteous fashion as I do,
Perforce, against all checkes, rebukes, and manners,
I must aduance the colours or my loue,
And not retire. Let me haue your good will.

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Good mother, do not marry me to yond foole:

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: I meane it not, I seeke you a better husband.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: That's my master, Master Doctor.

lg.l: Alas I had rather be set quicki'th earth,
And bowl'd to death with Turnips.
Come, trouble not your selfe good Master
Fenton, I will not be your friend, nor enemy:
My daughter will I question how she loues you,
And as I finde her, so am I affected;
Till then, farewill Sir, she must needs go in,
Her father will be angry.

sp.speaker: Fen
sp.p: Farewell gentle Mistris; farewell Nan.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: This is my doing now; Nay, saine I, will you cast away your childe on a Foole, and a Physitian:
Looke on Master Fenton, this is my doing.

lg.l: I thanke thee: and I pray thee once to night,
Giue my sweet Nan this Ring: there's for thy paines:

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Now heauen send thee good fortune, a kinde heart he hath: a woman would run through fire and water for such a kinde heart. But yet, I would my Master had Mistris Anne, or I would Master Slender had her: or (in sooth) I would Master Fenton had her; I will doe what I can for them all three, for so I haue promised, and ile be as good as my word, but speciously for Master Fenton. Well, I must of another errand to Sir Iohn Falstaffe from my two Mistresses: what a beast am I to slacke it.

div.head: Scoena Quarta▪
div.stage: Enter Falstaffe, Bardolfe, Quickly, Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Bardolfe I say.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Heere Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Go, fetch me a quart of Sacke, put a tost in't. Haue I liu'd to be carried in a Basket like a barrow of butchers Offall? and to be throwne in the Thames? Wel, if I be seru'd such another tricke, ile haue my braines ' tane out and butter'd, and giuen them to a dogge for a New-yeares gift: The rogues slighted mee into the Riuer with as little remorse, as they would haue drown'de ablinde bitches Puppies, fifteene i'th litter: and you may know by my size, that I haue a kinde of alacrity in sinking: if the bottome were as deepe as hell, I should downe. I had beene drown'd, but that the shore was sheluy and shallow; a death that I abhorre: for the water swelles a man; and what a thing should I haue beene, when I had beene swel'd? I should haue beene a Mountaine of Mummie.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Here's M. Quickly Sir to speake with you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Come, let me poure in some Sacke to the Thames water: for my bellies as cold as if I had swallow'd snow-bals, for pilles to coole the reines. Call her in.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Come in woman.

lg.l: By your leaue; I cry you mercy?
Giue your worship good morrow.
Take away these Challices;
Go, brew me a pottle of Sacke finely.

sp.speaker: Bard.
sp.p: With Egges, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Simple of it selfe; Ile no Pullet-Spersme in my brewage. How now?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Marry Sir, I come to your worship from M. Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mis. Ford? I haue had Ford enough; I was thrown into the Ford, I haue my belly full of Ford.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Alas the day, (good-heart) that was not her fault; she do's so take on with her men; they mistooke their promise▪ erection.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: So did I mine, to build vpon a foolish Womans

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Well, she laments Sir for it, that it would yern your heart to see it; her husband goes this morning a birding; she desires you once more to come to her, betweene eight and nine; I must carry her word quickely, she'll make you amends I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, I will visit her, tell her so▪ and bidde her thinke what a man is; Let her consider his frailety, and then iudge of my merit.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: I will tell her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Do so. Betweene nine and ten saist thou?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Eight and nine Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, be gone; I will not misse her.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Peace be with you Sir.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I meruaile I heare not of Master Broome; he sent me word to stay within; I like his money well: Oh, heere he comes.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Blesse you Sir.

lg.l: Now M. Broome, you come to know
What hath past betweene me, and Fords wife.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: That indeed (Sir Iohn) is my businesse.

lg.l: M. Broome I will not lye to you,
I was at her house the houre she appointed me.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And sped you Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Very ill fauouredly M. Broome.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: How so sir, did she change her determination?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No (M. Broome) but the peaking Curnuio her husband (M. Broome) dwelling in a continnall larum of ielousie, comes me in the instant of our encounter, after wee had embrast, kist, protested, and (as it were) spoke the prologue of our Comedy▪ and at his heeles, a rabble of his companions, thither prouoked and instigated by his distemper, and (forsooth) to search his house for his wiues Loue.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What? While you were there?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: While I was there.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And did he search for you, and could not find you?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: You shall heare. As good lucke would haue it, comes in one Mist. Page, giues intelligence of Fords approach: and in her inuention, and Fords wiues distraction, they conuey'd me into a bucke-basket.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: A Buck-basket?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Yes, a Buck-basket: ram'd mee in with foule Shirts, and Smockes, Socks, foule Stockings, greasie Napkins, that (Master Broome) there was the rankest compound of villanous smell, that euer offended nostrill.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And how long lay you there?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Nay, you shall heare (Master Broome) what I haue suffered, to bring this woman to euill, for your good: Being thus cram'd in the Basket, ● couple of Fords knaues, his Hindes, were cald forth by their Mistris, to carry mee in the name of foule Cloathes to Datchet lane; they tooke mee on their shoulders met the iealous knaue their Master in the doore; who asked them once or twice what they had in their Basket? I quak'd for feare lest the Lunatique Knaue would haue search'd it: but Fate (ordaining hee should bee a Cuckold) held his hand: well, on went hee, for
a search and away went I for foule Cloathes; But marke the sequell (Master Broome) I suffered the pangs of three seuerall deaths: First, an intollerable fright, to bee detected with a iealious rotten Bell▪ weather: Next to bee compass'd like a good Bilbo in the circumference of a Pecke, hilt to point, heele to▪ head. And then to bee stopt in like a strong distillation with stinking Cloathes, that fretted in their owne grease thinke of that, a man of my Kidney; thinke of that; that am as subiect to heate as butter; a man of continuall dissolution, and thaw: it was a miracle to scapesuffocation. And in the height of this Bath (when I was more then halfe stew'd in grease (like a Dutchdish) to bee throwne into the Thames, and coold, glowing hot, in that serge like a Horse-shoo; thinke of that; hissing hot: thinke of that (Master Broome.)

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: In good sadnesse Sir, I am sorry, that for my sake you haue sufferd all this.
My suite then is desperate: You'll vndertake her no more?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Master Broome: I will bee throwne into E●ta, as I haue beene into Thames, ere I will leaue her thus; her Husband is this morning gone a Birding, I haue receiued from her another ambassie of meeting; 'twixt eight and nine is the houre (Master Broome.)

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: 'Tis past eight already Sir,

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Is it? I will then addresse mee to my appointment; Come to mee at your conuenient leasure, and you shall know how I speede: and the conclusion shall bee crowned with your enioying her: adiew; you shall haue her (Master Broome) Master Broome, you shal cuckold Ford.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p:
Hum: ha? Is this a vision? Is this a dreame? doe I sleepe? Master Ferd awake, awake Master Ford▪
ther's a hole made in your best coate (Master Ford:) this 'tis to bee marryed; this 'tis to haue Lynnen, and Buck-baskets: Well, I will proclaime my selfe what I am▪ I will now take the Leacher; hee is at my house; hee cannot scape mee; 'tis impossible hee should: hee cannot creepe into a halfe-penny purse, not into a Pepper-Boxe. But lest the Diuell that guides him, should aide him, I will search impossible places: though what I am, I cannot auoide; yet to bee what I would not, shall not make me tame; If I haue hornes, to make one mad, let the prouerbe goe with mee, ile bee horne-mad.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Mistris Page, Quickly, William, Euens:

sp.speaker: Mis Page.
sp.p: Is he at M. Fords already think'st thou?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Sure hee is by this; or will bee presently; but truely hee is very couragious mad, about his throwing into the water. Mistris Ford desires you to come sodainely.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Ile be with her by and by; ile but bring my yong-man here to Schoole; looke where his Master comes; 'tis a playing day I see: how now Sir Hugh, no Schoole to day?

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: No, Master Slender is let the Boyes leaue to play.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: ‛ Blessing of his heart.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Sir Hugh, my husband saies my sonne profits nothing in the world at his Booke; I pray you aske him some questions in his Accidence.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: Come hither William; hold vp your head; come.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Come-on Sirha; hold vp your head; answere your Master, be not afraid.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: William, how many Numbers is in Nownes?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Two.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Truely, I thought there had bin one Number more, because they say od's-Nownes.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Peace, your tatlings. What is (Faire) William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Pulcher.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.p: Powlcats? there are fairer things then Powlcat, sure.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: You are a very simplicity o'man; I pray you peace. What is (Lapis) William?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A Stone.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: And what is a Stone (William?)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: A Peeble.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: No; it is Lapis; I pray you remember in your praine.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Lapis.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: That is a good William; what is he (William) that do's lend Articles:

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Articles are borrowed of the Pronoune; and be thus declined▪ Singulariter nominatiuo hic haec, hoc.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Nominatiuo hig, hag, hog; pray you marke; genitiue huius; Well: what is your Accusatiue-case?

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Accusatiue hinc.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I pray you haue your remembrance (childe) Accusatiuo hing, hang, hog.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Hang-hog, is latten for Bacon, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Leaue your prables (o'man) What is the Focatiue case (William?)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: O, Vocatiuo, O.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Remember William, Focatiue, is caret:

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: And that's a good roote.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: O'man,, forbare.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Peace.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: What is your Genitiue case plurall (William?)

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Genitiue case?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Genitiue horum, harum, horum.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Vengeance of Ginyes case; fie on her; neuer name
her (childe) if she be a whore.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: For shame o'man.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: You doe ill to teach the childe such words: hee teaches him to hic, and to hac; which they'll doe fast enough of themselues, and to call horum; fie vpon you.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: O'man,, art thou Lunaties? Hast thou no vnderstandings for thy Cases, and the numbers of the Genders? Thou art as foolish Christian creatures, as I would desires.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Pre'thee hold thy peace.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Shew me now (William) some declensions of your Pronounes.

sp.speaker: Will.
sp.p: Forsooth, I haue forgot.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: It is Qui, que, quod; if you forget your Quies, your Ques, and your Quods, you must be preeches: Goe your waies and play, go.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: He is a better scholler then I thought hee was.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: He is a good sprag▪ memory: Farewel Mis. Page.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Adeu good Sir Hugh.
Get you home boy, Come we stay too long.

div.head: Scoena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Falstaffe, M. Ford, Mist. Page. Seruants, Ford, Page, Caius, Euans Shallow.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Mis. Ford, Your sorrow hath eaten vp my sufferance; I see you are obsequious in your loue, and I professe requitall to a haires bredth, not onely Mistris Ford, in the simple office of loue, but in all the accustrement complement, and ceremony of it: But are you sure of your husband now?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Hee's a birding (sweet Sir Iohn.)

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: What hoa▪ gossip Ford; what hoa.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Step into th' chamber, Sir Iohn▪

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p:
How now (sweet heart) whose at home▪
besides your selfe?

sp.speaker: Mis Ford.
sp.p: Why none but mine owne people.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Indeed?

sp.speaker: Mis. Frod.
sp.p: No certainly; Speake louder.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Truly, I am so glad you haue no body here.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Why woman, your husband is in his olde lines againe; he so takes on yonder with my husband, so railes against all married mankind; so curses all Eues daughters, of what complexion soeuer; and so buffettes himselfe on the for-head; crying peere-out, peere-out, that any madnesse I euer yet beheld, seem'd but tamenesse, ciuility, and patience to this his distemper he is in now. I am glad the fat Knight is not heere,

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Why, do's he talke of him?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Of none but him, and sweares hee was caried out the last time hee search'd for him, in a Basket; Protests to my husband he is now heere, and hath drawne him and the rest of their company from their sport, to make another experiment of his suspition: But I am glad the Knight is not heere; now hee shall see his owne foolerie.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: How neere is he Mistrs Page?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Hard by, at street end; he will be here anon▪

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: I am vndone, the Knight is heere:

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Why then you are vtterly sham'd, and hee's but a dead man. What a woman are you? Away with him, away with him; Better shame, then murther.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Which way should he goe? How should I bestow him? Shall I put him into the basket againe?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: No, Ile come no more i'th Basket.
May I not goe out ere he come?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Alas: three of Master Fords brothers watch the doore with Pistols, that none shall issue out: otherwise you might slip away ere hee came: But what make you heere?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What shall I doe? Ile creepe vp into the chimney.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: There they alwayes vse to discharge their Birding-peece: creepe into the Kill▪ hole.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Where is it?

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Hee will seeke there on my word; Neyther Presse, Coffer, Chest, Trunke, Well, Vault, but hee hath an abstract for the remembrance of such places, and goes to them by his Note; There is no hiding you in the house.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Ile goe out then:

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: If you goe out in your owne semblance, you die Sir Iohn, vnlesse you go out disguis'd.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: How might we disguise him?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Alas the day I know not, there is no womans gowne bigge enough for him: otherwise he Might put on a hat, a muffler, and kerchiefe, and so escape.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Good hearts, diuise something; any extremitie, rather then a mischiefe.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: My Maids Aunt the fat woman of Brainford, has a gowne aboue.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: On my word it will serue him: shee's as big as he is; and there's her thrum'd hat, and her muffler▪ too: run vp Sir Iohn.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Go, go, sweet Sir Iohn: Mistris Page and I will looke some linnen for your head.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Quicke, quicke, wee'le come dresse you straight: put on the gowne the while.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: I would my husband would meete him in this shape; he cannot abide the old woman of Brainford; hee sweares she's a witch, forbad her my house, and hath threatned to beate her.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Heauen guide him to thy husbands cudgell; and the diuell guide his cudgell afterwards.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: But is my husband comming?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: I in good sadnesse is hee, and talkes of the basket too, howsoeuer he hath had intelligence.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Wee'l try that: for ile appoint my men to carry the basket againe, to meete him at the doore with it, as they did last time.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Nay, but hee'l be heere presently: let goe dresse him like the witch of Brainford.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Ile first direct my men, what they shall doe with the basket: Goe vp, ile bring linnen for him straight.

lg.l: Hang him dishonst Varlet,
We cannot misuse enough:
Well leaue a proofe by that which we will doe,
Wiues may be merry, and yet honest too:
We do not acte that often, iest, and laugh,
'Tis old, but true, Still Swine eats all the draugh.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Go Sirs, take the bas basket againe on your shoulders: your Master is hard at doore: if he bid you set it downe, obey him▪ quickly, dispatch.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: Come, come, take it vp.

sp.speaker: 2 Ser.
sp.p: Pray heauen it be not full of Knight againe.

sp.speaker: 1 Ser.
sp.p: I hope not, I had liefe as beare so much lead.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I, but if it proue true (Master Page) haue you any way then to vnfoole mee againe. Set downe the basket villaine: some body call my wife: Youth in a basket: Oh you Panderly Rascals, there's a knot: a gin, a packe, a conspiracie against mee. Now shall the diuel be sham'd-What wise I say: Come, come forth: behold what honest cloathes you send forth to bleaching.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Why, this passes Master Ford, you are not to goe loose any longer, you must be pinnion'd.

sp.speaker: Euan●:
sp.p: Why, this is Lunaticks: this is madde, as a mad dogge.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: In deed Master Ford, this is not well indeed.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: So say I too Sir, come hither Mistris Ford, Mistris Ford, the honest woman, the modest wife, the vertuous creature▪ that hath the iealous foole to her husband: I suspect without cause (Mistris) do I?

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Heauen be my witnesse you do, if you suspect me in any dishonesty.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well said Brazen-face, hold it out: Come forth sirrah.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: This passes.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Are you not a sham'd, let the cloths alone.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I shall finde you anon.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: 'Tis vnreasonable; will you take vp your wiues cloathes? Come, away.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Empty the basket I say.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Why man, why?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Master Page, as I am a man, there was one conuay'd out of my house yesterday in this basket: why may not he be there againe, in my house I am sure hee is; my Intelligence is true, my iealousie is reasonable, plucke mee out all the linnen.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: If you find a man there, hee shall dye a Fleas death.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Heer's no man.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: By my fidelity this is not well Master Ford: This wrongs you.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: Master Ford, you must pray, and not follow the imaginations of your owne heart: this is iealousies.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well, hee's not heere I seeke for.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: No, nor no where else but in your braine.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Helpe to search my house this one time: if I find not what I seeke, shew no colour for my extremity; Let me for euer be your Table-sport; Let them say of me, as iealous as Ford, that search'd a hollow Wall-nut for his wiues Lemman. Satisfie me once more, once more serch with me.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: What hoa (Mistris Page,) come you and the old woman downe; my husband will come into the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Old woman? what old womans that?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Why it is my maids Aunt of Brainford.

sp.speaker: Ford:
sp.p: A witch, a Queane, an olde couzening queane: Haue I not forbid her my house. She comes of errands, do's she? We are simple men, wee doe not know what's brought to passe vnder the profession of Fortune telling, She workes by Charmes, by Spels, by th' Figure, and such dawbry as this is, beyond our Element: wee know nothing. Come downe you Witch, you Hagge you, come downe I say.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Nay, good sweet husband, good Gentlemen, let him not strike the old woman.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Come mother Prat, Come giue me your hand.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Ile Prat-her: Out of my doore, you Witch, you Hagge, you Baggage, you Poulcat, you Runnion, out, out: Ile coniure you, ile fortune tell you.

lg.l: Are you not a sham'd?
I thinke you haue kill'd the poore woman.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Nay hee will do it, 'tis a goodly credit for you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Hang her witch.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: By yea, and no, I thinke the o'man is a witch indeede: I like not when a o'mans has a great peard; I spie a great peard vnder his muffler.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Will you follow Gentlemen, I beseech you follow; see but the issue of my iealousie. If I cry out thus vpon no traile, neuer trust me when I open againe.

lg.l: Let's obey his humour a little further;
Come Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Trust me he beate him most pittifully.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Nay by th' Masse that he did not; he beate him most vnpittifully, me thought.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Ile haue the cudgell hallow'd, and hung ore the Altar, it hath done meritorious seruice.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: What thinke you? May wee with the warrant of woman-hood, and the witnesse of a good conscience, pursue him with any further reuenge?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: The spirit of wantonnesse is sure scar'd out of him, if the diuell haue him not in fee-simple, with find & recouery, he will neuer (I thinke) in the way of waste, attempt vs againe.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Shall wee tell our husbands how wee haue seru'd him?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Yes, by all meanes: if it be but to scrape the figures out of your husbands braines: if they can find in their hearts, the poore vnuertuous fat Knight shall be any further afflicted, wee two will bee still the ministers.

sp.speaker: Mist. Ford.
sp.p: Ile warrant, they'l haue him publiquely sham'd, and me thinkes there would be no period to iest, should he not be publikely sham'd.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Come, to the Forge with it, then shape it: I would not haue things coole.

div.head: Scoena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Host and Bardolfe.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Sir, the Germane desires to haue three of your horses: the Duke himselfe will be to morrow at Court, and they are going to meet him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What Duke should that be comes so secretly? I heare not of him in the Court: let me speake with the Gentlemen, they speake English?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: I Sir, Ile call him to you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: They shall haue my horses, but Ile make them pay: Ile sauce them, they haue had my houses a weeke at commaund. I haue turn'd away my other guests they must come off, Ile sawce them, come.

div.head: Scoena Quarta▪
div.stage: Enter Page, Ford, Mistris. Page, Mistris Ford, and Euans.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: 'Tis one of the best discretions of a o'mans as euer I did looke vpon.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And did he send you both these Letters at an instant?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Within a quarter of an houre.

lg.l: Pardon me (wife) henceforth doe what thou wilt:
I rather will suspect the Sunne with gold,
Then thee with wantonnes: Now doth thy honor stand
(In him that was of late an Heretike)
As firme as faith.
'Tis well, 'tis well, no more:
Be not as extreme in submission, as in offence,
But let our plot go forward: Let our wiues
Yet once againe (to make vs publike sport)
Appoint a meeting with this old fat-fellow,
Where we may take him, and disgrace him for it.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: There is no better way then that they spoke of.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: How? to send him word they'll meete him in the Parke at midnight? Fie, fie, he'll neuer come.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: You say he has bin throwne in the Riuers: and has bin greeuously peaten, as an old o'man: me-thinkes there should be terror in him, that hee should not come: Me-thinkes his flesh is punish'd, hee shall haue no desires,

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: So thinke I too.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Deuise but how you'l vse him when he comes, And let vs two deuise to bring him thither.

lg.l: There is an old tale goes, that Herne the
Hunter (sometime a keeper heere in Windsor Forrest)
Doth all the winter time, at still midnight,
Walke round about an Oake, with great rag'd hornes,
And there he blasts the tree, and takes the cattle,
And make milch-kine yeeld blood, and shakes a chaine
In a most hideous and dredfull manner.
You haue heard of such a Spirit, and well you know
The superstitious idle-headed-Eld
Receiu'd, and did deliuer to our age
This tale of Herne the Hunter, for a truth.
Why yet there want not many that do feare
In deepe of night to walke by this Hernes Oake:
But what of this?
Marry this is our deuise,
That Falstaffe at that Oake shall meete with vs.
Well, let it not be doubted but he'll come,
And in this shape, when you haue brought him thether,
What shall be done with him? What is your plot?
That likewise haue we thoght vpon and thus:
Nan Page (my daughter) and my little sonne,
And three or foure more of their growth, wee'l dresse
Like Vrchins, Ouphes, and Fairies, greene and white,
With rounds of waxen Tapers on their heads
And rattles in their hands; vpon a sodaine,
As Falstaffe, and I, are newly met,
Let them from forth a saw▪ pitrush at once
With some diffused song: Vpon their sight
We two, in great amazednesse will flye:
Then let them all encircle him about,
And Fairy-like to pinch the vncleane Knight;
And aske him why that houre of Fairy Reuell,
In their so sacred pathes, he dares to tread
In shape prophane.
And till he tell the truth,
Let the supposed Fairies pinch him, sound,
And burne him with their Tapers.
The truth being knowne.
We'll all present our selues; dis-horne the spirit,
And mocke him home to Windsor.
The children must
Be practis'd well to this, or they'll neu'r doo't.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: I will teach the children their behauiours & I will: be like a Iacke-an-Apes also, to burne the Knight with my Taber.

lg.l: That will be excellent,
Ile go buy them vizards.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: My Nan shall be the Queene of all the Fairies, finely attired in a robe of white.

lg.l: That silke will I go buy, and in that time
Shall M. Slender steale my Nan away,
And marry her at Eaton: go, send to Falstaffe straight.
Nay. Ile to him againe in the name of Broome,
Hee'l tell me all his purpose: sure hee'l come.
Feare not you that; Go get vs properties
And tricking for our Fayries.
Let vs about it,
It is admirable pleasures, and ferry honest knaueries.
Go Mis. Ford,
Send quickly to Sir Iohn, to know his minde;
Ile to the Doctor, he hath my good will,
And none but he to marry with Nan Page;
That Slender (though well landed) is an Ideot,
And he, my husband best of all affects;
The Doctor is well monied and friends
Potent at Court; he, none but he shall haue her,
Though twenty thousand worthier come to craue her.

div.head: Scoena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Host, Simple, Falstaffe, Bardolfe, Euans, Cains, Quickly.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What wouldst thou haue? (Boore) what? (thick skin) speake, breathe, discusse; breefe, short, quicke, nap.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Marry Sir, I come to speake with Sir Iohn Falstaffe from Master Slender.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: There's his Chamber, his House, his Castle his standing bed and truckle-bed: 'tis painted about with the story of the Prodigall, fresh and new: goe, knocke and call: hee'l speake like an Anthropophaginian vnto thee; Knocke I say.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There's an olde woman, a fat woman gone vp into his chamber; ile be so bold as stay Sir till she come down I come to speake with her indeed.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Ha▪ A fat woman? The Knight may be robb'd; Ile call. Bully-Knight, Bully Sir Iohn; speake from thy Lungs Military; Art thou there? It is thine Host, thine Ephesian cals.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: How now mine Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Here's a Bohemian-Tartar taries the comming downe of thy fat-woman. Let her descend (Bully) let her descend▪ my Chambers are honourable; Fie, priuacy? Fie.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: There was (mine Host) an old-fat-woman euen now with me, but she's gone.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Pray you Sir, was't not the Wise-woman of Brainford?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I marry was it (Mussel-shell) what would you with her?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My Master (Sir) my master Slender, sent to her seeing her go thorough the streets, to know (Sir) whether one Nim (Sir) that beguil'd him of a chaine, had the chaine or no▪

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I spake with the old woman about it.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: And what sayes she, I pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Marry shee sayes, that the very same man that beguil'd Master Slender of his Chaine, cozon'd him of it.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I would I could haue spoken with the Woman her selfe, I had other things to haue spoken with her too, from him.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What are they? let vs know.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I; come, quicke.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I may not conceale them (Sir.)

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Conceale them, or thou di'st.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Why sir, they were nothing but about Mistris Anne Page, to know if it were my Master fortune to haue her, or no.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: 'Tis, 'tis his fortune▪

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: What Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: To haue her, or no: goe; say the woman told me so.

sp.speaker: Simple
sp.p: May I be bold to say so Sir?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I Sir: like who more bold.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I thanke your worship: I shall make my Master glad with these tydings.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thou are clearkly; thou art clearkly (Sir Iohn) was there a wise woman with thee?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I that there was (mine Host) one that hath taught me more wit, then euer I learn'd before in my life: and I paid nothing for it neither, but was paid for my learning.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Out alas (Sir) cozonage: meere cozonage.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Where be my horses? speake well of them varletto.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Run away with the cozoners: for so soone as I came beyond Eaton, they threw mee off, from behinde one of them, in a slough of myre; and set spurres, and away; like three Germane-diuels; three Doctor Faustaffes.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: They are gone but to meete the Duke (villaine) doe not say they be fled: Germanes are honest men.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: Where is mine Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What is the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Euan:
sp.p:
Haue a care of your entertainments: there is a friend of mine come to Towne, tels mee there is three Cozen-Iermans, that has cozened all the Hosts of Readius,
of Maidenhead; of Cole-brooke, of horses and money: I tell you for good will (looke you) you are wise, and full of gibes, and vlouting-stocks: and 'tis not conuenient you should be cozoned. Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Ver'is mine Host de Iarteere?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Here (Master Doctor) in perplexitie, and doubtfull delemma.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I cannot tell vat is dat: but it is tell-a-me, dat you make grand preparation for a Duke de Iamanie: by my trot; der is no Duke that the Court is know, to come▪ I tell you for good will; adieu.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Huy and cry, (villaine) goe: assist me Knight, I am vndone: fly, run: huy, and cry (villaine) I am vndone.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I would all the world might bee cozond, for I haue beene cozond and beaten too: if it should come to the eare of the Court, how I haue beene transformed; and how my transformation hath beene washd, and cudgeld, they would melt mee out of my fat drop by drop, and liquor Fishermens-boots with mee: I warrant they would whip mee with their fine wits, till I were as crest-falne as a dride-peare I neur prosper'd since I forswore my selfe at Primero: well, if my winde were but long enough; I would repent; Now? Whence come you?

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: From the two parties forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: ●●e Diuell take one partie, and his Dam the other: and so they shall bee both bestowed; I haue suffer'd more for their sakes; more then the villanous inconstancy of mans disposition is able to beare.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: And haue not they suffer'd? Yes, I warrant; speciously one of them; Mistris Ford (good heart) is beaten blacke and blew, that you cannot see a white spot about her.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
What tell'st thou mee of blacke, and blew? I was beaten my selfe into all the colours of the Rainebow:
and I was like to be apprehended for the Witch of Braineford, but that my admirable dexteritie of wit, my counterfeiting the action of an old woman deliuer'd mee, the knaue Constable had set meith ' Stocks, ith' common Stocks, for a Witch.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Sir: let me speake with you in your Chamber, you shall heare how things goe, and (I warrant) to your content: here is a Letter will say somewhat: (good-hearts) what a-doe here is to bring you together? Sure, one of you do's not serue heauen well, that you are so cross'd.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Come vp into my Chamber.

div.head: Scoena Sexta.
div.stage: Enter Fenton, Host.

lg.l: Master Fenton, talke not to me, my minde is heauy:
I will giue ouer all.
Yet heare me speake; assist me in my purpose,
And (as I am a gentleman) ile giue thee
A hundred pound in gold, more then your losse.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I will heare you (Master Fenton) and I will▪ (at the least) keepe your counsell.

lg.l: From time to time, I haue acquainted you
With the deare loue I beare to faire Anne Page,
Who, mutually, hath answer'd my affection,
(So farre forth, as her selfe might be her chooser)
Euen to my wish; I haue a letter from her
Of such contents, as you will wonder at;
The mirth whereof, so larded with my matter,
That neither (singly) can be manifested
Without the shew of both: fat Falstaffe
Hath a great Scene; the image of the iest.
Ile show you here at large (harke good mine Host;)
To night at Hernes-Oke, iust 'twixt twelue and one,
Must my sweet Nun present the Fairie Queene;
The purpose why, is here▪ in which disguise
While other lests are something ranke on foote,
Her father hath commanded her to slip
Away with Slender, and with him, at Eaton
Immediately to Marry; She hatst consented▪ Now Sir,
Her Mother, (euen strong against that match
And firme for Doctor Caius) hath appointed
That he shall likewise shuffle her away,
While other sports are tasking of their mindes,
And at the Deanry, where a Priest attends
Strait marry her: to this her Mothers plot
She (seemingly obedient) likewise hath
Made promise to the Doctor; Now, thus it rests,
Her Father meanes she shall be all in white;
And in that habit, when Slender sees his time
To take her by the hand, and bid her goe.
She shall go with him; her Mother hath intended
(The better to deuote her to the Doctor;
For they must all be mask'd, and vizarded)
That quaint in greene, she shall be loose en-roab'd,
With Ribonds pendant, flaring'bout her head;
And when the Doctor spies his vantage ripe,
To pinch her by the hand, and on that token,
The maid hath giuen consent to go with him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Which meanes she to deceiue? Father, or Mother.

lg.l: Both (my good Host) to go along with me:
And heere it rests, that you'l procure the Vicar
To stay for me at Church, 'twixt twelue, and one,
And in the lawfull name of marrying,
To giue our hearts vnited ceremony.
Well, husband your deuice; Ile to the Vicar,
Bring you the Maid, you shall not lacke a Priest.
So shall I euermore be bound to thee;
Besides, ile make a present recompence.

div.head: Scoena Prima.
div.stage: Enter Falstaffe, Quickly, and Ford.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Pre'thee no more pratling; goe, ile hold, this is the third time: I hope good lucke lies in odde numbers: Away, go, they say there is Diuinity in odde Numbers, either in natiuity, chance, or death: away.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Ile prouide you a chaine, and ile do what I can to get 〈◊〉 a paire of hornes.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Away I say, time weares, hold vp your head and mince. How now Master Broome? Master Broome, the matter will be knowne to night, or neuer. Bee you in the Parke about midnight, at Hernes-Oake, and you shall see wonders.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Went you not to her yesterday (Sir) as you told me you had appointed?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I went to her (Master Broome) as you see, like a poore-old-man, but I came from her (Master Broome) like a poore-old-woman; that same knaue (Ford her husband) hath the finest mad diuell of iealousie in him (Master Broome) that euer gouern'd Frensie. I will tell you, he beate me greeuously, in the shape of a woman: (for in the shape of Man (Master Broome) I feare not Goliah with a Weauers beame, because I know also, life is a Shuttle) I am in hast, go along with mee, ile tell you all (Master Broome:) since I pluckt Geese, plaide Trewant, and whip● Top, I knew not what'twas to be beaten, till lately-Follow me, ile tell you strange things of this knaue Ford, on whom to night I will be reuenged, and I will deliuer his wife into your hand. Follow, strange things in hand (Master Broome) follow.

div.head: Scena Secunda.
div.stage: Enter Page, Shallow, Slender.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Come, come: wee'll couch i'th Castle-ditch, till wee see the light of our Fairies. Remember sonne Slender, my

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I forsoothe, I haue spoke with her, and wee haue a nay-word, how to know one another. I come to her in white, and cry Mum; she cries Budget, and by that we know one another.

sp.speaker: Shal.
sp.p: That's good too: But what needes either your Mum, or her Budget? The white will decipher her well enough. It hath strooke ten a▪ clocke.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: The night is darke, Light and Spirits will become it well: Heauen prosper our sport. No man meanes euill but the deuill, and we shall know him by his hornes. Lets away: follow me.

div.head: Scoena Tertia.
div.stage: Enter Mis. Page, Mis. Ford, Caius.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Master Doctor, my daughter is in green, when you see your time, take her by the hand, away with her to the Deanerie, and dispatch it quickly; goe before into the Parke; we two must goe together.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I know vat I haue to do, adieu.

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: Fare you well (Sir:) my husband will not reioyce so much at the abuse of Falstaffe, as he will chafe at the Doctors marrying my daughter; But 'tis no matter; better a little chiding, then a great deale of heart-breake.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p:
Where is Nan now? and her troope of Fairies?
and the Welch-deuill Herne?

sp.speaker: Mist. Page.
sp.p: They are couch'd in a pit hard by Hernes Oake, with obscur'd Lights; which at the very instant of Falstaffes and our meeting, they will at once display to the night.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: That cannot choose but amaze him.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: If he be not amaz'd, he will be mock'd; If he be amaz'd, he will euery way be mock'd.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Wee'll betray him finely.

lg.l: Against such Lewdsters, and their lechery,
Those that betray them, do no treachery.

sp.speaker: Mi. Ford.
sp.p: The houre drawes-on; to the Oake, to the Oake.

div.head: Scoena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Euans and Fairies.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: Trib, trib Fairies; Come, and remember your parts: be pold (I pray you) follow me into the pit, and when I giue the watch-'ords, do as I pid you; Come, come trib, trib.

div.head: Scoena Quarta.
div.stage: Enter Falstaffe, Mistris Page, Mistris Ford, Euans, Anne Page, Fairies, Page, Ford, Quickly, Slender, Fenton, Caius, Pistoll.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
The Windsor-bell hath stroke twelue: the Minute drawes on: Now the hot-bloodied▪ Gods assist mee; Remember loue, thou was't a Bull for thy Europa, Loue set on thy hornes. O powerfull Loue, that in some respects makes a Beast a Man: in some other, a Man a beast. You were also (Iupiter) a Swan, for the loue of Leda: O omnipotent Loue, how nere the God drew to the complexion
of a Goose: a fault done first in the forme of a beast, (O Ioue, a beastly fault:) and then another fault, in the semblance of a Fowle, thinke on't (Ioue) a fowlefault. When Gods haue hot backes, what shall poore men doe? For me, I am heere a Windsor Stagge, and the fattest (I thinke) i'th Forrest. Send me a coole rut-time (Ioue) or who can blame mee to pisse my Tallow? Who comes heere my Doe?

lg.l: Sir Iohn? Art thou there (my Deere?)
My male-Deere?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: My Doe, with the blacke Scut? Let the skie raine Potatoes: let it thunder, to the tune of Greene-sleeues, haile-kissing Comfit, and snow Eringoes; Let there come a tempest of prouocation, I will shelter mee heere.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford.
sp.p: Mistris Page is come with me (sweet heart.)

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Diuide me like a brid'd-Bucke, each a Haunch: I will keepe my sides to my selfe, my shoulders for the fellow of this walke; and my hornes I bequeath your husband. Am I a Woodman, ha? Speake I like Herne the Hunter? Why, now is Cupid a child of conscience, he makes restitution. As I am a true spirit, welcome.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Alas, what noise?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Heauen forgiue-our sinnes.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: What should this be?

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: M. Page. Away, away.

lg.l: I thinke the diuell will not haue me damn'd,
Lest the oyle that's in me should set hell on fire;
He would neuer else crosse me thus.

div.stage: Enter Eairies.

lg.l: Fairies blacke, gray, greene, and white,
You Moone-shine reuellers, and shades of night.
You Orphan heires of fixed destiny,
Attend your office, and your quality.
Crier Hob-goblyn, make the Fairy Oyes.
Elues, list your names: Silence you aiery toyes.
Cricket, to Windsore-chimnies shalt thou leape;
Where fires thou find'st vnrak'd, and hearths vnswept,
There pinch the Maids as blew as Bill-berry,
Our radiant Queene, hates Sluttery.
They are Fairies, he that speaks to them shall die,
Ile winke, and couch: No man their workes must eie.
Wher's Bede? Go you, and where you finde a maid
That ere she sleepe has thrice her prayers said,
Raise vp the Organs of her fantasie,
Sleepe she as sound as carelesse infancie,
But those as sleepe, and thinke not on their sins,
Pinch them armes, legs, backes, shoulders, sides, and shins.
About, about:
Search Windsor Castle (Elues) within, and out:
Strew good lucke (Ouphes) on euery sacred roome,
That it may stand till the perpetuall doome,
In state as wholsome, as in state 'tis fit,
Worthy the Owner, and the Owner it.
The seuerall Chaires of Order, looke you scowre
With iuyce of Balme; and euery precious flower,
Each faire Instalment, Coate, and seu'rall Crest,
With loyall Blazon, euermore be blest.
And Nightly-meadow-Fairies, looke you sing
Like to the Garters-Compasse, in a ring,
th'Expressure that it beares: Greene let it be,
Mote fertile-fresh then all the Field to see;
And, Hony Soit Qui Mal-y-Pence, write
In Emrold ruffes, Flowres purple, blew; and white,
Like Saphire-pearle, and rich embroidery,
Buckled below faire Knight-hoods bending knee;
Fairies vse Flowres for their characterie:
Away, disperse: But till 'tis one a clocke,
Our Dance of Custome, round about the Oke
Of Herne the Hunter, let vs not forget.
Pray you locke hand in hand: your selues in order set.
And twenty glo-wormes shall our Lanthornes bee
To guide our Measure round about the Tree.
But stay, I smell a man of middle earth.
Heauens defend me from that Welsh Fairy,
Lest he transforme me to a peece of Cheese.

sp.speaker: Pistoll.
sp.p: Vilde worme, thou wast ore-look'd euen in thy birth.

lg.l: With Triall-fire touch me his finger end;
If he be chaste, the flame will backe descend
And turne him to no paine: but if he start,
It is the flesh of a corrupted hart.

sp.speaker: Pist.
sp.p: A triall, come.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Come: will this wood take fire?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh.

lg.l: Corrupt, corrupt, and tainted in desire.
About him (Fairies) sing a scornfull rime,
And as you trip, still pinch him to your time.

lg.head: The Song.
lg.l: Fie on sinnefull phantasie: Fie on Lust, and Luxirie.
Lust is but a bloudy fire, kindled with vnchaste desire,
Fed in heart whose flames aspire,
As thoughts do blow them higher and higher:
Pinch him (Fairies) mutuall: Pinch him for his villanie.
Pinch him, and burne him, and turne him about,
Till Candles, and Star-light, and Moone-shine be out.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Nay doe not flye, I thinke wee haue watcht you now; Will none but Herno the Hunter serue your turne?

lg.l: I pray you come, hold vp the iest no higher.
Now (good Sir Iohn) how like you Windsor wiues?
See you these husband? Do not these faire yoakes
Become the Forrest better then the Towne?

sp.speaker: Ford.

lg.l: Now Sir, who's a Cuckold now?
Master Broome, Falstaffes a Knaue, a Cuckoldy knaue,
Heere are his hornes Master Broome;

sp.p: And Master Broome, he hath enioyed nothing of Fords, but his Buck-basket, his cudgell, and twenty pounds of money, which must be paid to Master Broome, his horses are arrested for it, Master Broome.

sp.speaker: M. Ford.
sp.p: Sir Iohn, wee haue had ill lucke: wee could neuer meete: I will neuer take you for my Loue againe, but I will alwayes count you my Deere.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I doe begin to perceiue that I am made an Asse.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I, and an Oxe too; both the proofes are extant.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: And these are not Fairies;

I was three or foure times in the thought they were not Fairies, and yet the guiltinesse of my minde, the sodaine surprize of my powers, droue the grossenesse of the foppery into a receiu'd beleefe, in despight of the teeth of all rime and reason, that they were Fairies. See now how wit may bee made a Iacke-a-Lent, when 'tis vpon ill imployment.

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: Sir Iohn Falstaffe, serue Got, and leaue your desires, and Fairies will not pinse you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Well said Fairy Hugh:

sp.speaker: Euans.
sp.p: And leaue you your iealouzies too, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: I will neuer mistrust my wife againe, till thou art able to woo her in good English.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Haue I laid my braine in the Sun, and dri'de it, that it wants matter to preuent so grosse ore-reaching as this? Am I ridden with a Welch Goate too? Shall I haue a Coxcombe of Frize? Tis time I were choak'd with a peece of toasted Cheese.

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: Seese is not good to giue putter; your belly is all putter.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p:
Seese, and Putter? Haue I liu'd to stand at the taunt of one that makes Fritters of English? This is enough
to be the decay of lust and late-walking through the Realme.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Why Sir Iohn, doe you thinke though wee would haue thrust vertue out of our hearts by the head and shoulders, and haue giuen our selues without scruple to hell, that euer the deuill could haue made you our delight?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: What, a hodge-pudding? A bag of flax?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: A puftman?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Old, cold, wither'd, and of intollerable entrailes?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And one that is slanderous as Sathan?

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: And as poore as Iob?

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: And as wicked as his wife?

sp.speaker: Euan.
sp.p: And giuen to Fornications, and to Tauernes, and Sacke, and Wine, and Metheglins, and to drinkings and swearings, and starings? Pribles and prables?

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: Well, I am your Theame: you haue the start of me, I am deiected: I am not able to answer the Welch Flannell, Ignorance it selfe is plummet ore me, vse mee as you will.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: Marry Sir, wee'l bring you to Windsor to one Master Broome, that you haue cozon'd of money, to whom you should haue bin a Pander: ouer and aboue that you haue suffer'd, I thinke, to repay that money will be a biting affliction.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Yet be cheerefull Knight: thou shalt eat a posset to night at my house, where I will desire thee to laugh at my wife, that now laughes at thee: Tell her Master Slender hath married her daughter.

sp.speaker: Mis. Ford▪
sp.p: Doctors doubt that;
If Anne Page be my daughter, she is (by this) Doctour Caius wife.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Whoa hoe, hoe, Father Page,

lg.l: Sonne? How now Sonne.
Haue you dispatch'd?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: Dispatch'd? Ile make the best in'Glostershire know on't: would I were hang'd la, else.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Of what sonne?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I came yonder at Eaton to marry Mistris Anne Page, and she's a great lubberly boy. If it had not beene i'th Church, I would haue swing'd him, or hee should haue swing'd me. If I did not thinke it had beene Anne Page, would I might neuer stirre, and 'tis a Post-masters Boy.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: Vpon my life then, you tooke the wrong.

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: What neede you tell me that? I thinke so, when I tooke a Boy for a Girle: If I had beene maried to him, for all hee was in womans apparrell) I would not haue had him.

lg.l: Why this is your owne folly,
Did not I tell you how you should know my daughter, By her garments?

sp.speaker: Slen.
sp.p: I went to her in greene, and cried Mum, and she cride budget, as Anne and I had appointed, and yet it was not Anne, but a Post-masters boy.

sp.speaker: M. Page.
sp.p: Good George be not angry, I knew of your purpose: turn'd my daughter in white, and indeede shee is now with the Doctor at the Denerie, and there married.

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: Ver is Mistris Page: by gar I am cozoned, I ha married oon Garsoon, a boy; oon pesant, by gar. A boy, it is not An Page, by gar, I am cozened.

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Why? did you take her in white?

sp.speaker: Cai.
sp.p: I bee gar, and 'tis a boy; be gar Ile raise all Windsor.

sp.speaker: Ford.
sp.p: This is strange: Who hath got the right Anne?

lg.l: My heart misgiues me, here comes Master Fenton▪
How now Master Fenton?

sp.speaker: Anne.
sp.p: Pardon good father, good my mother pardon

lg.l: Now Mistris;
How chance you went not with Master Slender?

sp.speaker: Mis. Page.
sp.p: Why went you not with Master Doctor, maid?

lg.l: You do amaze her: heare the truth of it.
You would haue married her most shamefully,
Where there was no proportion held in loue:
The truth is, she and I (long since contracted)
Are now so sure that nothing can dissolue vs,
Th'offence is holy, that she hath committed,
And this deceit looses the name of craft,
Of disobedience, or vnduteous title,
Since therein she doth euitate and shun
A thousand irreligious cursed houres
Which forced marriage would haue brought vpon her.
Stand not amaz'd, here is no remedie:
In Loue, the heauens themselues do guide the state,
Money buyes Lands, and wiues are sold by fate.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: I am glad, though you haue tane a special stand to strike 〈◊〉 that your Arrow hath glanc'd.

lg.l: Well, what remedy? Fenton, heauen giue thee ioy,
What cannot bee eschew'd, must be embrac'd.

sp.speaker: Fal.
sp.p: When night-dogges run, all sorts of Deere are chac'd.

lg.l: Well, I will muse no further: Master Fenton,
Heauen giue you many, many merry dayes:
Good husband, let vs euery one go home,
And laugh this sport ore by a Countrie fire,
Sir Iohn and all.
Let it be so (Sir Iohn:)
To Master Broome, you yet shall hold your word,
For he, to night, shall lye with Mistris Ford.
